reviewText:
*sigh* where to start. It's 2015, why is a game of this caliber is being locked at 30fps? While the frame rate cap is editable, you have to go into the config to do it instead of the main menu. But that doesn't matter, the game is terribly optimized. Whether it's capped at 30 or 60fps, you'll get major framerate drops. A single GTX 970 isn't even enough to keep it at a stable 30fps, which is completely ludicrous. Warner Brothers should be ashamed of releasing a game like this.

What makes it worse is that, at the very last hour, they edited the Steam sub for the people that got the free Nvidia copy for buying a GTX 970 or 980 so that they wouldn't get the Harley Quinn pre-order bonus. Why do that? You already give away a free game, why take away a little pre-order bonus that everyone else who pre-ordered would get?

It just ends up making a lot of people angry. For months now people have been asking whether or not the people who got the Nvidia free copy would be getting the Harley Quinn pack. They were completely unclear on it, just beating around the bush.

This is no way to treat your fans.

At this point, this game isn't worth buying because of technical issues and such a terrible practice by it's publisher. Even people who got this game for free must feel like they got betrayed right now.

Save your money, wait for updates and play something else in the mean time. I recommend the Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, a game that is much more optimized for PC, developed by a group of people who actually care about their fans.

Update 1: No patch yet, but after some tinkering in the config file. I've gotten the game to run at a somewhat more stable frame rate. If I stand still or move slowly I can maintain a stable 60fps, but as soon as I hop into the Batmobile or start gliding around, frame rate will start dropping anywhere from 50's down to the low 20's. The worst part is every now and then the frame rate would tank so hard it would go down to single digit, like several other people have noticed. So I guess for right now, maintaining a stable 60fps or even 30fps is impossible unless you want to play Batman: Walking Simulator.

Update 2: I got a chance to play the game a little bit, so this post will be about the gameplay. The combat and control are great and responsive, You never felt quite more like Batman than you are in this game. You feel powerful. The entire Gotham City is your playground and it feels amazing to traverse it. The only problem I have with the gameplay is that driving the Batmobile in Pursuit Mode" felt pretty bad. It was hard to turn around corners without smashing into something
date: combining with the terrible frame rate and let just say I rather just glide across Gotham City than drive the Batmobile. I really hope they tweak the control for the Batmobile
recommended: it's my least favorite thing about the game right now. "Battle Mode" however is great
hoursPlayed: only because it's alot easier to maneuver around with it on."

reviewText:
Updated 10/29 for the PC re-release that happened on 10/28:

Many of the worst issues in the original release of this game have been resolved, but if it came out as-is today I would still say the port is pretty disappointing. Many people who couldn't play the game at all before can get a playable framerate now, but even on a very high end system the frame pacing is very poor and results in a stuttery experience.

The texture loading issues that plagued the game on release are gone, but you still see shockingly low resolution textures during almost any cut scene.

Image quality is all over the board, but is improved quite a bit by turning off AA, CA, and film grain effects.

Speaking of effects, there seems to be a bug that scales the intensity of post-processing effects with the screen resolution the game renders at. The most obviously visible occurance of this bug is when lens flares are rendered. In 1080p, lens flares look more or less as they should. At 1440p you'd think Batman just had LASIK surgery because looking at a street light produces a double or triple lens flare corona that makes it very difficult to see what is going on. Considering the whole game takes place at night and there are more lens flares than a JJ Abrams movie this bug can get pretty irritating.

If you're a huge batman fan and you've been waiting to play this game, I'd say it is definitely playable now. If you're on the fence and were waiting to see whether they had turned a legendarily bad release into a good one for rerelease, I'd say wait until it is heavily discounted.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Original review of initial release version:


One of the worst PC ports of all time.

This game had some incredibly misleading advertising. In the Nvidia gamework promo reel, posted to youtube by Nvidia on June 6 (only a few weeks before the game was released), they show ambient occlusion and rain textures - both of which are present in the console versions, and entirely absent from the PC version. The same gameworks promo trailer is also a full 60fps, but the game ships with a 30fps cap. By editing an .ini file you can remove the 30fps cap, but many have reported that causes other graphical issues such as textures only loading the very lowest detail level (they look pretty similar to the textures from a Nintendo 64 game).

Aside from the false advertising, this game can't even maintain a consistent framerate on hardware that FAR exceeds the recommended specifications. For example, despite having the game installed on an SSD, and running a 980ti with the latest drivers, I still get dips into single digit framerates in many situations. For example, any time I get in the batmobile, I am watching a slide show for a few seconds.

Save your money and wait to buy this game until it is fixed (if it ever does get fixed).

reviewText:
POST PATCH UPDATE

My did this take a while, well the game has now had a major patch and things are...better. The game is still by default held at 30fps but now an option in the menu has been added that lets you choose between 30/60/90 fps although they do say if you put it above 60 you may experience some issues with the performance. In my experience the game runs much better than before I get a solid 60fps on maximum settings (not including NVIDIA crap) during fighting/walking/gliding/grappling with almost no hitching, however I must say while driving the batmobile you can get 60 around the outskirts of Gotham but in the center where its busy and there are more npc's and other cars it does drop to around 50fps quite frequently. While this is not great it is certainly better than the 20fps it used to be when driving the batmobile.

The options menu has had loads of changes more suitable to PC with texture settings actually having an option for High" this time rather than just medium which brings me to the games graphics. The game looks marginally better although not really in any significantly noticeable way. While batman games always had that shiny polished look to all its textures

reviewText:
Edit 30/10/2015  People are still commenting on this review so I'm making this edit to let people know this wasn't updated to reflect current patches in the game.  I returned the product shortly after it was released.  There has since been two performance patches which reportedly improve things.  I decided not to purchase it again as it's so close to November when other games launch and my time is limited ATM.

*** If your interested in purchasing the game look for more current reviews. ***


---

Played it for around an hour so far.

The combat is fun and responsive, the gliding is great and the game looks okay (AF is set to 4 by default which makes some textures look awful).  That's the good parts.

The bad parts are the framerate issues which are all over the place and the batmobile.  The game will frequently pause or dip to sub 10 fps on a gtx 970 when entering or approaching new areas.  Cutscenes have similar issues to witcher 3 in that while in engine they run at even less fps (by default the game itself is locked to 30, tweakable in the ini files) than the normal game making them stutter or appear stilted.

Summoning the batmobile causes major frame rate drops.  At one point I summoned the car to try the batmobile takedown move.  By the time the frame rate recovered the batmobile had crushed the pack of guys I was fighting including the Riddler henchman I wanted to interrogate.

The batmobile itself handles awfully.  There are forced batmobile sections which involve chasing targets such as tanks or vehicles.  The handling makes some turns difficult to pull off and the vehicle feels clunky.  Some have recommended turning into a tank for a small amount of time for more precise control but this kills all momentum.  Tank mode is really boring but necessary to take out armored vehicles.  If you eject while under attack from armored vehicles batman will get upset someone is wrecking his car.  There doesn't appear to be a way (yet) to deal with vehicles without the batmobile which ruins the feel of the prior batman games.  Hopefully the need for the batmobile is limited later in the game.

Unless this is patched soon it's definitely a refund.  I bought the game based on the prior Rocksteady Batman titles which played well on launch but this is a terrible PC port.  Never really expected the game to turn out this way but I guess alarm bells should have triggered when there was no PC review prior to launch.

Edit:

For those commenting my PC is below min specs. It's not

Win 7SP1
i5 3570k
8gigs ram
SSD
970 GTX

If you want to see what the gameplay was like for me see this video by RPS.  It was less frequent than in the video but it's the exact same symtoms.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=37KpOYVrLZM

reviewText:
As much that i hate downvoting a great game, this titel deserve it.. I'm running a 970 with a i7 4790k and getting 30 FPS and alot of problems (stutter, soundbugs etc). I have waited and was really hyped to play this game and it saddest me too se the PC port be so bad this time around.

(Please read the updates i do in this review if you have some questions or disagreed with me)

Pros:
Looks like a great history (only 3 hours in the game)
Fun combat system with amazing cool combos
Driving the BATMOBILE :o
Really huge world to play in. Alot of things to do.

Cons:
Bad performance.
30fps LOCK
Stutter, soundbugs, etc.
Bad looking textures.
Really bad PC port.

Buy this game? If you dont mind the problems atm, i would pick it up BUT not for full price.

Thanks for reading the review. :)

Update 23-06-2015:
Okay, you can remove the 30FPS lock, by going to your go to this in your steam library:
G:\Steam\steamapps\common\Batman Arkham Knight\Engine\Config

Then double click on BaseSystemSettings"

Then press ctrl+f and type in "fps" and now you can change that to 60 but i dont recomend going over 60 as it will most likley crash.

I still stand by the review even tho you can remove the 30FPS cap. This is 2015 and a game that release on PC should not have been capped at all.

reviewText:
1. Horrible stuttering where the framerate is anywhere between 60 and 3  FPS when I glide or drive on my Radeon 290x.
2. 30 FPS Lock on a PC release is unforgivable.
3. NVIDIA Game Works things hammered in that makes the performance of AMD cards worse, Thanks for being a part of the team NVIDIA and Rocksteady.
4. Price of the Season Pass is too high for the amount of content that has been revealed to be included.
5. The native Anti-Aliasing in the game options still gives the game horrible jaggies. The option is either on or off for it.

reviewText: Batman confronts the ultimate threat against the city he has been sworn to protect. The Scarecrow returns to congeal an imposing array of glitches, including sporadic freezes, frame-rate stutters, and audio glitches, to summarily destroy The Dark Knight. The game introduces Rocksteady's uniquely-designed imagining of the Batmobile, occasionally drivable, for the first time in the franchise. Batman: Arkham Knight offers gamers a complete Batman experience as they rip through community forums, system config files, and eventually a bottle of Jack Daniels, all in an attempt to discover the exceptional game that lies just out of reach.

reviewText:
Yet another AAA title that fails actual playtesting and is shipped out to unsuspecting consumers who hoped it might not actually run like balls. Given this game runs on Unreal Engine 3, an engine pushing over 11 years old at this point, it has performance that makes GTA IV run like any Source game in comparison.

Rocksteady have in the past demonstrated great optimisation in previous titles. My old laptop, which ran a GT 555m graphics card could maintain 60 fps in Arkham Asylum on the highest settings. This game, on my GTX 970 (which is one of the top 10 best graphics cards currently on the market) can barely push 40 fps stationary, and between 5-30 whilst moving. Good thing we got that enhanced NVIDIA driver to improve our performance!

I think the worst part is that graphics wise, its not really much of an improvement over its predecessors. The post processing effects look really nice, and the rain effects are pretty gorgeous, but the overall texture and model quality just barely look better than Arkham Asylum, and that game came out NEARLY SIX YEARS AGO.

I cannot recommend this to anyone until they fix the performance issues. Also, you can tell its probably a shoddy console port because the left the 30 fps cap in the .ini file. Stay classy, Rocksteady.

reviewText: DisclaimerThis review" is meant to be a blemish of Warner Brothers publisher for what they've released on PC on June 23
date: 2015. Negative words about the game mean technical state of PC version of Batman: Arkham Knight at the moment of the launch. All the information I refer to can be easily checked on the internet
recommended: I give almost no references here.\n\nWhat Happened?I'm sure I can not write what happen at the launch of Batman AK on PC. In a nutshell: crashes

voteText: on both AMD and Nvidia setups)

votesTotal: it was reflected in tons of negative feedback from community and press. Steam Store had superior percentage of negative reviews. The game was pulled from sale on Steam which never ever happened before as far as I know. Users were offered to refund the game and Green Man Gaming (games online store) even started refunds for BAK though they don't do it on regular basis as it's stated in their Terms and Conditions and Refund Policy.\n\nWho to Blame?Much sh*t was poured on Rocksteady (BAK developers) and on "external PC development partner" Iron Galaxy Studios (studio that ported the game to PC). It's clear that the first were responsible for the game in general and console versions of it in particular and Rocksteady did its job quite good as far as I'm concerned. IGS is made guilty more often (they were doing PC version of the game

commentsCount: but I refuse to do so. They're experienced[en.wikipedia.org] enough in developing
column16:
porting and assisting in porting games for various platforms. They ported Bioshock: Infinite to PC and The Handsome Collection (Borderlands 2 and Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel) to PS4 and XBox One after all. I wouldn't judge them unless I knew the conditions they were set and time they were given to do their job.

But I know who to blame for sure - Batman Arkham Knight publisher Warner Bros.

Quick FactsWB made decision to have console versions of the game as primary ones (which is
column17: sadly
column18: a common practice nowadays) and to outsource porting to PC. It didn't happen to previous Batman games made by Rocksteady. Quite likely this decision was made just to save money on PC version because sales on PC are lower comparing to consoles.\nWB didn't give much sh*t about testing the game on PC. Anonymous sources say PC version of BAK was tested by 10% of sources (while PC is more complex than consoles) and in 720p. Standard resolution for PC gamers

reviewText:
I can't recommend the game in its current condition. Who cares about the 30FPS cap because that's an easy fix in the .ini files. The stuttering and freezing, however, happens even on the lowest settings, and it is unfixable. I've never played a game with stuttering this bad before, and I've played games with a dying GPU.

I'm giving this game the two weeks before I refund it, which I probably can't due to it being from a third-party. My review will change when the game is playable.

EDIT 2: I recently had to upgrade my video card from an nVidia GTX 680 2gb to a GTX 970 4gb. Does the game run any better? Sort of.. The stutter issues don't happen so immediate, though they start appearing after extended play. Plus, with this video card, there should be no reason for these low framerates on normal" settings in an Unreal Engine 3 game.

EDIT 3: Thanks to the new video card
date: I've been able to play it a little more and I've discovered the Harley Quinn DLC can be completed in a mere 19 minutes. Unless she can be used as a challenge mode character (like Catwoman/Robin/Nightwing in Arkham City) this pre-order DLC is truly garbage."

reviewText:
*Edit*  2015/09/04 My game actually runs worse post-patch...

First off, this is an inexcusably terrible port, especially from a developer whose budget vastly exceeds the million dollar mark, I find it ironic that they delayed the Limited Edition due to quality issues yet were perfectly content with releasing this broken, incomplete mess as it is on PC. The FPS is locked to 30 by default and suffers dips to the single digits when moving fast due to what I suspect to be a texture streaming issue, while there is an option to unlock it, it's best left on as it creates instabilities and the constant drops from 60 FPS to 10 - 20 FPS make for an annoying experience. I hope the Steam refund is used in wide effect, this trend of games launching in such state is getting rather tiresome.

The game itself is mediocre - featuring the same overly simple, monotonous combat from the previous installments and most of the same gadgets only this time you get access to the Bat Mobile, which does create a few cool moments but soon becomes extremely repetitive when you're forced to use it on nearly every mission in the game. The voice acting is horrible, beyond the 'so bad it's good' mark, it comes across as tired and uninspired where the characters in-game sound like they care little for the current situation with a stiff, almost sarcastic tone and hardly ever fits the mood of the moment at hand.  The world features some nice design choices and looks pretty good in my opinion, the aesthetics of the game are not too shabby either.

The plot is laughably bad, this is lower grade writing defined - not that I care much for it in most games, but in a game like this that's heavily narrative driven it's... bad. The characters are pretty dull and generic too, along with their cringe worthy dialogue that makes for plenty of moments where you're likely to let out a sigh, it's as if they read a few comic books, watched some of the movies & cartoons and took the cheesiest, most generic lines they could find and threw them in there.

While this is essentially the same Batman game as before and you're likely to find some enjoyment out of it if you don't mind the monotony of being forced to use the Batmobile for a good portion of the game and if you really liked the other ones and are a fan of Batman in general, I'd recommend waiting atleast a year for them to iron this mess out and get a version inclusive with the swamp of DLCs planned - I,myself, will never buy anything from this studio again, their attitude is awful and they clearly shafted PC gamers to the bottom of the pedestal, like most AAA devs of this era do.

reviewText: At this moment in time, the game is broken, and not just a normal broken, but broken in a way that some people will find it very unenjoyable. You can fix the 30 fps problem by editing the ini files (Lord knows why they locked it in the first place, but that's not the point.)\nI have a 2gig GTX 960, it's obviously the biggest regret of my rig so far but I'm waiting for the next line of GPU's to come out before I waste my money on a 980ti. I have stuttering when turning the camera, when driving, etc. It's crazy bad even on the lowest settings. I do get 60 fps in a majority of areas, but as soon as I turn the camera or drive it dips in the 40s. It's sad because the game stutters even worse when I lock it back at 30 fps.\nIt's just flat out broken concerning performance, and I really wish to enjoy the game. The arkham games are some of my favorite games of all time, and I will give a positive review once these performance problems are fixed. Until then, save your money.

reviewText:
I had the graphics on full settings until around halfway through the game when it lagged out so much that I thought I had suddenly returned to the game E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial.
However, I will try to focus on the actual game instead of the graphics.

Good:

- Interesting story
- Good number of returning villains
- Interesting villains, not just boring ones (with the exception of the Riddler)
- Funny thug dialogue
- Good, new fighting mechanics (not including the Batmobile)
- Allows you to use the Batmobile
- Introduces new classic characters (Lucius Fox, Red Hood, Man-Bat)
- Gives returning characters more development along with their own missions (Azrael, Firefly, Deathstroke)
- DLC isn't just rehashed ideas
- Good references and easter eggs

Bad:

- Story gets repetitive in some places
- Some returning villains have extremely boring side missions (Riddler, Deathstroke, Hush)
- New villains also have extremely boring side missions (Pyg, Deacon Blackfire)
- Riddler riddles are getting REALLY BORING
- You have to solve all 243 riddles to complete the game 100%, which is complete bullsh*t
- Deathstroke, the only villain who can match Batman's skill, is reduced to a tank battle boss fight
- Fan-favourite villains aren't in the game (Deadshot, Bane, Mr Freeze)
- The Batmobile is overused, and it is used in almost all side missions at least 3 times
- The Batmobile removes the need for avoiding sentry guns, allowing you ro just run them over
And an honourable mention:
- Rocksteady completely ignored PC gamers and focused on Xbox and PS

reviewText:
*This review will be addressing the actual in gameplay and story aspects, NOT the technical issues. There's plenty of reviews covering those*

I got Arkham Asylum when it came out. One of my favorite games, ever. Same with Arkham City. I beat both of those games on PS3, and beat AA again on PC and will do City on PC shortly, and I rarely re-beat games.

I don't know what happened to Arkham Knight. There are no boss battles in this game. None. There are a few souped up tanks/helicopters you fight with the Batmobile that could qualify as a boss battle, but there are not any actual hand to hand combat boss battles. You have no boss battle with Arkham Knight. You have no boss battle with Scarecrow. You have no boss battle with Harley Quinn, or Penguin, or Deathstroke. Why? Back in City/Asylum, Mr. Freeze is considered one of the best boss battles of all time. Ra Al Guul, Poision Ivy, EXCELLENT battles. You have almost a century's worth of material from films, games, comics, and tv shows to look for inspiration to how a 1v1 boss battle could be played out. Why are these not there? Like what a stupid design decision. I guess that's the most jarring part is just that there's just no good reason to not put them in. it's not like there were time/money constraints. As I said you have Batmobile boss battles where you fight unique tanks and what not. Why not allocate some of those sources to a real battle? I mean really, there was no Arkham Knight boss battle? None? And with the backstory they gave the guy, there is no reason he wouldn't have been able to have a huge epic fight with Batman. It's just so stupid.

Also, the story. The story is really good at some points. But I kinda wonder if there isn't some DC Executive ♥♥♥♥in with the stories cause he thinks he knows what he's doing better than Rocksteady. because Joker steals the show. again. Yes I know he died at the end of City. I know Rocksteady confirmed that absolutely Joker would not be in the game. Well, they lied. Joker's in the game, and he has more recorded dialogue than Scarecrow and Arkham Knight combined.

The Batmobile segments weren't bad in theory. I don't know why people say the Batmobile is tough to control, I think it's very smooth. The combat of it, in theory, is complex, strategic, and fun. It has a variety of fun weapons to play with.

Except all the actual fights with the Batmobile were just incredibly uninspired. Like with the exception of two fights, the dozens of tank fights in the game is just you in an empty area with a bunch of takes. Hit 'Fire' and strafe until everything stops moving. There's no 'tactical' way to assert the situations. You just strafe and ♥♥♥♥. the AI is also incredibly unfair at somepoints. basically, the way enemy tanks attack is that shoot in a straight line, and it's telegraphed for ~1 sec by an indicator line from the tank that traces the hits area of effect. Sometimes, when you're fighting 50+ tanks simultaneously (which btw sounds epic but is really just tedious) you see the lines pop up and there is LITERALLY (i used that in the traditional, non hyperbolic meaning) no way you could possibly dodge. Not that you can't react fast enough. I mean there is literally no possible button input in which you could possibly dodge some of the ♥♥♥♥ thrown at you. None nada. It doesn't happen often, it's the result of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ deal of the RNG, since attacks are more aimed at the Batmobile's general area rather than right at you. but still just stupid. Part of the problem also is it's almost like Rocksteady thinks that every time you fight a big crowd as Batman, there has to be some complimentary batmobile fight/segment. No, there doesn't. When you show some intimidating crowd attacking Batman, you don't need to do a tank squadron right after. Geez, why does this have to be explained? Why would you think this? That's like fanfiction logic.

Now the actual hand to hand combat was really done well. It was very refined, and it's not just Arkham City with new attacks/enemies. The core gameplay is the same, but it's done in a way where you handle situations a lot differently than you would in AC. It feels inspired, like they had ideas about the combat that they were excited about implementing. For example, you get a voice sysnthesizer that can be used to direct an enemy to a certain location by a false voice of their commander. It makes you rethink the way Predator encounters are done. There's a LOT of nice touches like that.

Overall, get this game if you liked the other Arkham games, but do not expect the holy pinnacle of the Batman series. Just expect some more Arkham style mayhem that can be frustrating but usually fun. If you haven't played any other Arkham games, go get Arkham City or Asylum. This and Origins are the ones who to save for those who really liked the previous 2 and want more.

reviewText:
This game's PC port is not good, even according to my benchmarks. I have had several issues with this game so far and here is the list:

Graphics are lacking; it could have been much better for PC. However, the console versions look great.
Performance tends to drop when moving through one city to another.
Sometimes turning off VSync and AA improves performance, but not by much.
When racing through tracks, using the Riddler Blocker tends to pause the game every half second that it's activated. Unsure if that is input lag according to the controller.
Stuttering occurs frequently in the game when moving throughout for some, even that it becomes unplayable for some who first drive the batmobile.
Vsync locks it to 30 frames which signifies poor performance and/or implementation.
My advice: Wait for a patch and more reviews to release, but skip for now if you have a minimum-requirement computer. A future review may be in the works later down the line. I'll update the review as I go along with further updates and announcements.

6/27/15 UPDATE #1: An announcement has been posted stating that Rocksteady and Iron Galaxy Studios are now focusing on the performance and graphical fidelity for the PC version. A user named   Batsassin has posted an improvement of graphical fidelity here (the left image is the improvement) http://i.imgur.com/hV7ZNH0.jpg

Frame drops in the range of below 3fps, 30fps at best. Simply unplayable due to the frame drops.

Edit: Changing the maximal fps in the .ini and reinstalling the game improves the performance by a lot. But it is still a bad port and the DRM issue remains.

Edit (29.10.15): Key issues like no SLI/Crossfire and paging issues (FPS drop the longer you play) are still untouched, so don't get deceived by the relaunch!

reviewText:
I'll add my two cents to the flame.

I'm a batman fan. I've read pretty much all the modern comics with his appearances, watched films, played the games, watched tv shows.

So imagine my excitement with the announcement of this game.

I have an AMD FX-8370 with a GTX 970. 8GB RAM. I run games like The Witcher 3 at max, save for hairworks and a notch lower on shadows and foilage. I've never seen a framedrop, even in Novigrad. That should demonstrate that there isn't anything wrong with my system. I've run taxing tests to be sure using different benchmark utilities, and I get within the same ballpark as other recorded scores of this video card.

I don't think PC games can be expected to run 100% amazing right out of the box. It's a difficult thing to accomplish. With the numerous different PC configurations that everybody around the world has, it's an undertaking that few games have managed to accomplish. Of course, it's absolutely fantastic if they do, but I don't hate it when a couple of ini tweaks are necessary for smooth gameplay. It's the nature of the beast. That being said, the lack of a bloody slider for mouse sensitivity is pretty stupid. The previous games in the series didn't even have that, if I'm remembering correctly. Even with my tolerance for doing fixes on my own, this is one of the worst that I've seen.

I've tried everything. I've even given up the dream of a full 60 frames per second, and used that terrible recommendation that they posted on their forums: Telling users that don't have a 980 to run all the settings at normal. I couldn't even maintain a stable 30 framerate with those settings. I've tried numerous ini tweaks outlined in the steam forums, none of which, unfortunately, seem to make a difference. I jacked the ini file that the tweak guide author posted on pastebin and tried that (even though I essentially copied his guide to begin with). Didn't work.

The bottom-line is that this game doesn't work properly for the vast majority of players. Of course, there are outliers out there, who claim to be able to run the game great. Do I think they're lying? No. Maybe their configuration just works better than the rest of us for whatever reason. But there's no denying that the vast majority of players, even with good builds, are unable to run this game at a stable framerate.

I bought the game on GMG, so a steam refund isn't applicable to me. Luckily, GMG, bless their souls, has stated that if the issues aren't fixed by the next patch, they'll issue refunds to everybody who bought from them.

All I wanted to do was play as the ♥♥♥♥ing batman.

Edit: With the new patch, 30 fps lock is now playable. There are minor drops few and far between, but it doesn't drop to 18 fps for me anymore.

reviewText: I have two GTX 970s and an i5 4690k processor. The year is 2015. I disabled the 30fps cap and the game bounces between 30fps and 60fps to the point at which it's unplaybable, and don't tell me the game is playable at 30fps, I KNOW it is, but guess what, my rig cost me $1600, it can run Far Cry 4 in 4k on ultra settings at a stable 60fps, I should be able to run Arkham Knight just as well. I didn't spend that money to get a copy of a game that runs worse then it does on a glorified shoebox that's only good for casual gamers and people who like exclusives (I am the latter). Just because it would run better on my PS4 doesn't mean I should just fork up $60 for the title just to see it run at 30fps at 1080p with low to medium textures, which by the way are all that you can basically use in the game, because not enough time was put into the PC port. Luckily I merely got this game for free for buying my GTX 970s, but even then this feels like a ripoff. I'll repeat that. This game is so poorly optimized for PC that I got it for FREE, and I still feel like it was a bad deal. I'm waiting for a patch to decide whether or not to uninstall this game from my 2 terabyte hard drive which, shocker, there's still plenty of space on. It's not that this is a bad game as far as gameplay goes, which speaking honestly is the most important aspect of a game, so is it fair for me to give this title a fully negative review? No. But at this point I cannot suggest to anybody to buy this game on any platform if you care about the PC community, because people that want to pay top dollar for the best product should GET the best product. That's how capitalism has always worked, and another pillar of it is that we all vote with our wallets. So please PC community, for the love of all that is holy, do not buy this title on PC. If you want to stop production companies like WB and Ubisoft from putting out games that don't have good PC ports, then don't buy them. I don't care how much you want to be batman, go back and play Arkham City if you care that much. This game is not worth $60, I honestly feel like I should be compensated for even spending any time trying to get this game to run as it should on my PC. I understand some people will see my viewpoint as unreasonable, and I completely understand, but I entirely refuse to accept that this is the best that a large scale video game production company can do. I'm aware that they outsourced this to the same people that screwed up Arkham Origins, I don't blame the company that did the port I blame Warner Bros. for choosing them and pushing them to meet a deadline that they clearly couldn't. This entire situation infuriates me, and I have no doubt that another such game will come along in a few months and do the same. But for now Warner Bros. has my full attention and hatred. Please heed my words, and consider what is best for the PC community. DO. NOT. BUY. THIS. GAME. Pretty please. With sprinkles on top. Screw Warner Bros. With love, cleanshot.

reviewText:
Fantastic game and all, combat, story and visual. It has almost everything from the previous games which makes the Arkham series great.

Imo the game lacks a bit 1on1 boss fights, for example (MINOR SPOILER) the fight with Deathstroke, i mean come on, 1 punch and Deathstroke is KO'd? lol.

Only thing it lacks from my view is the 1on1 fights which all the previous games did a great job with.

Despite all that Batman Arkham Knight is a great game.

BUT, it still doesn't justify the games current state. It is filled with bugs, bugs that should not even be in a game when it is released.

It breaks my heart as a big Batman fan to give my favourite comic book hero a downvote, i hope to change this to upvote in the near future.

TLDR;
GREAT BATMAN GAME PROBABLY THE BEST IMO, BUT HOLD ONTO YOUR MONEY TILL ALL THE PROBLEMS HAVE BEEN FIXED.

reviewText:
Updated:

I'll try to make this quick and informative based on what I have played so far.

It is a port pure and simple, it plays and feels as though it was developed for a console and not a PC. While mouse and keyboard controls are not the worst, they could be better. I ended up switching to a controller and the game did seem to play more smooth.

AMD users got the short end of the stick yet again so they will have to wait for a patch which is getting quite old to be honest, Witcher 3, Project CARS and now Batman: Arkham Knight.

The FPS cap can be tweaked in the ini files which does help the game run more smooth so I would reccomend trying that, the cutscenes are also locked at 30 fps so it will stutter during cutscenes. But just looks like a re-skinned (horribly optimized) version of all the previous games running on the exact same engine.

C'mon rocksteady.... really?

One thing I have not seen anyone talk about is SLI, and I have had major SLI issues with the game, all them come while running the nvidia gameworks settings turned on. While the game does perform better it also has much bigger downsides, ntdll.dll crashes for some, lots of random flickering in the screen for me that did not happen when SLI was turned off. Some SLI users (myself included) have even gotten the always fun BSOD. Oh, and 4K has had some serious reported issues that make the game unplayable and I'm sure there are many more yet to be discovered. Turning SLI off and running on one of the two GTX 970's seems to have removed some of these problems.

Pros:
Upgraded combat
Batmobile - fun to use
New bat-tools to use in game

Cons:
Bad performance
Unnecessary fps lock
Lack of in game options to help with performance
Bad port
Batmobile - will kill whatever fps you have left

In the current sate of the game maybe a 3.5/10

After more testing, few things to add:

SLI is broken for most people, try to stay away.
Try rolling back Nvidia drivers to the pre arkham drivers as that seemed to help some people, myself inculded, until batmobile arrives.
Running as admin seemed to help if you havent already tried this.
Still getting random crashes which is annoying.

On a positive note the combat is outright glorious, best combat in any game that features a combat system like this.

Will review again after we get an update, hopefully they get it right so I can recommend it.

reviewText:
I don't know what Rocksteady was doing for the past 3.5 years but they should have focused more on making a Batman game. When they first showed off the Batmobile I thought it would just be a neat way to travel the big open world, but sadly that is not the case. You will spend probably half your time playing this game in the Batmobile which doesn't control all that great. This ends up feeling more like Twisted Metal: Arkham than a Batman finale.

Pros

- No constant backtracking that has been so prevalent in Arkham games.
- Batman + ally sections. Can also be a con because it's used so scarcely and is a missed opportunity.

Cons

- Worst PC port of all time.
- Too much time spent in the Batmobile
- No boss fights
- Arkham Knight is a disappointment

This has 70% negative reviews and most of them are because of the performance, but honestly it is just that bad. On top of the game no working, there's just so little it does right and a whole lot it gets wrong. Scarecrow and Arkham Knight are supposed to be the antagonists but they feel secondar and even though it has been in development for ~3 years it feels rushed.

4/10

reviewText:
As a huge DC and Batman fan, I've religiously 100%ed the previous Arkham games with the exception of Batman: Arkham Origins (I gave up on the Predator Paragon achievement). It seems Batman: Arkham Knight will be another exception but for different reasons. I actually loved Origins despite its flaws but the more I think about this title... the more I realize it was a chore to play. Keep in mind I got the premium edition (base game + all DLC) for ~$24 USD off of Bundlestars when they were having a sale too.

I've got 149 hours and while I can say I've definitely got my money's worth, I can't say this is a good game. Before I cover the issues that annoyed me, I'd like to go over the positives first.

For starters, this game looks amazing -- there's no doubt about it. I've never seen an Unreal Engine 3 game that looks like this and I'm not just talking about the facial animations and expressions, I'm talking about everything. Another area the game excelled in was voice acting. Most characters were well cast and Kevin Conroy as Batman and a certain someone definitely were at the top of their game here. Also worth mentioning is the good twists and gotcha!" moments that totally caught me off guard. The soundtrack was similarly great and hit most of the right notes
date: making me almost cry in one scene. Building off what Arkham City gave us
recommended: we get even more combat moves and ways to initiate a silent takedown. Not only that
hoursPlayed: we finally get to drive around in the batmobile and tear down the streets in it. I can't downplay how exciting it is to hop into this awesome vehicle the first time and then find out it's a tank! Yes
voteText: the batmobile can transform in a matter of seconds into a tank which the game calls "Battle mode". There's tons of stuff you can do while in this mode and it's all really exciting stuff.\n\nBatmobile aside
helpfulPercent: there's no shortage of side missions and other little diversions happening while you fly around the map such as: thugs driving around in cars like hooligans or riots happening on the streets. If you've got the season pass there's also a ton of different batmobiles that you can test drive with authentic sounds and multiple characters you can play as in the AR challenges. My fondest memories are of playing the Adam West race tracks while hearing the TV show's theme song and playing as characters like Harley Quinn and Red Hood because of how unique they are. The best part of this game would have to be Photo Mode though. This wasn't even part of the base game upon launch but it was later added as a free update. A good 1/4 of my screenshots for this game were done in photo mode and what makes it great to use is that you can pause the game at any time
votesHelpful: choose "Photo Mode" from the pause menu
votesTotal: manipulate the camera angles
votesFunny: slap on a filter
commentsCount: zoom in or zoom out
column16: choose a border
column17:
and do it all in a way that's really easy to use. You end up getting some great looking screenshots like the one below. But unfortunately... all of this isn’t enough.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=655193795

Even though I’d say this is the best Arkham game for role-playing as Batman... there's such a thing as less is more. And damn does this apply to Arkham Knight. The batmobile's undoubtedly great but because the story mode over relies on it
column18: the fun factor disappears. Tank battle after tank battle and the game doesn't give up. Maybe I'm exaggerating but I reckon a good half of this game is spent in the batmobile. Winch this
column19: dodge these tanks and blow them up (it feels like an arcade game at times honestly)
column20: drive around and use this feature from the batmobile… and repeat. I really think the batmobile should've been optional and not forced in the way that it is. The batmobile just feels a bit too destructive at times as well. I laughed as I mowed over people and slammed into buildings leaving nothing but debris. In addition to all of what I've said
column21: the batmobile reduces the rather cool boss fights that we had in previous games to... yep
column22:
you guessed it... tank battles.

Want to battle Deathstroke? Tank battle. Want to battle the Arkham Knight? Tank battle. Want to battle Firefly? Batmobile pursuit (okay it's a bit different but still not much fun). It just shows a lack of creativity. Other side missions? Disabling bombs safely and destroying APC military vehicles. How? I won't even go there. Even some of The Riddler missions - one of my favourite Batman villains - are almost crippled because of this. I won't spoil anything but The Riddler has basically set up race tracks for your batmobile and you have to get to the finish line in time. Yay? Writing this just makes me upset at all the lost potential here (even a lot of the non-batmobile missions and sidemissions lack fun for some reason). I get Rocksteady wanted to spoil us with the batmobile as well as a large cast of villains but it came at the cost of quality and most of the game just feels extremely repetitive.

Next is the story. The writing here is noticeably weaker than any of the other Arkham games (might be because Paul Dini left) and the story has too many plot holes for my liking. Not to mention the identity of one of the villains in this game is incredibly easy to guess. There's a ridiculous amount of foreshadowing and what could've been a powerful reveal is mostly uneventful. Besides that
column23: to get the “True Ending” players are forced to beat every side mission and get 243/243 riddles. The true ending doesn’t even answer a lot of questions or provide much closure but locking something like this behind riddles is a very silly move. Thankfully there’s a 242/243 savegame on PCGamingWiki if you don’t feel up to the task. On the port side of things
column24: the game runs mostly decent but I had some issues that need to be addressed. The first: unlocking certain Steam achievements will actually make the game freeze for a second or two every time you satisfy the criteria once more for that achievement. I’m not joking. It’s all to do with the PCEngine.ini file. The second: I had around 13 crashes total across my playtime but 8 of those were in the same part of the story (analysing the crash site of a vehicle for someone that was kidnapped). You might not experience it
column25:
but it too has been another reported issue that remains unfixed.


Other negatives include the "Arkham episodes". 6 characters have a DLC mission made for them but 5 of them can be finished in less than 10 minutes. I could probably forgive this but these missions are divided into 3 sections with 3 short cutscenes usually. Combat room

You'll notice this with someone like Harley Quinn where there's a lack of things for her to climb or jump up to. When it comes to combat

column31: thug voiceovers are reused for most of the characters and maybe one line for some is changed. A good example would be "Batman's not going to save you now Robin!". For Nightwing? "Batman's not going to save you now Nightwing!". It's especially bad when these lines repeat over and over more than they ever did in Arkham City. Certain AR challenges have bugs where thugs stand still and do nothing. Other maps are just unfair and weren't made in mind with the current combat system (Iceberg Lounge and Catwoman's Revenge). I’ll stop here….\n\nI've written an essay but all I’ll say is this: the PC port's better now but this game is easily the weakest in this series. If I wasn't a person with a lot of patience and/or a hardcore achievement collector

reviewText:
This is a disastrous launch, stay the hell away from this game until they patch it properly, even though i wouldn't bet on it.

I'm running this on a oc'd 2600k@4.5Ghz and oc'd 970 @1080p with the latest drivers from nvidia. First of all, the framerate is capped at 30(!) fps. Great job devs, especially for a 2015 game. You can unlock it via the .ini file though, so let's ingnore this for now.

I am launching the game again ready to enjoy glorious 60 fps gameplay...
NOT! Even with all the gameworks crap turned off, i am getting dips to sub 30's while driving, gliding and various other situations making it pretty much unplayable at times. The graphics quality doesn't justify such terrible performance, i can't even imagine how the game runs on lower spec systems. Trying to tune the settings does little to no difference at all. Gpu usage in afterburner is unstable during gameplay from 40% to 80% which indicates the game is poorly coded and cant ulitilize gpus properly. Before you say my cpu is bottleneching my gpu, there are guys in the forums with latest oc'd intel cpus and TitanX facing the same issues.

Rocksteady already admitted here http://community.wbgames.com/t5/Support-for-PC/PC-Performance-issues-we-hear-you/m-p/571341#U571341 that they tossed the pc version of the game to an external PC development partner" so you can understand how much they appreciate us.

reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying I only recommend this game if you are invested in the trilogy's story, because it does end the trilogy and the story did have it's moments.  But as an overall game, it gets a C+ in comparison to Arkham City's A+ in my books.

This review is not about the ineptitude and failure to deliver a good port, or how the game runs.  Because for me the game ran perfectly fine.  I have a system that could run it at 60fps just fine.  I was one of the lucky ones.

Therefore I waited until I completed the game, and this will be a review of the actual game itself, and will contain spoilers.  For Knight and for Arkham City, maybe a little for Asylum, because I have to make this comparison.

If you were to ask me which of the Arkham games was the best.  Far and away it would be City.  Knight in comparison feels, lazy, and the Batmobile segments feel forced, far too often do you use the Batmobile for miniscule things, like Riddler tasks.  Why would the Riddler design a underground racetrack for the Batmobile?  His entire premise is about Riddles.

So why you ask is City a better game.  Well.  The Boss Battles.  Not only did City make you Feel" like the Batman

reviewText: The game runs ok for the most part on my MSI GTX 970 and i7-4790k. The Nvidia smoke settings screw you and there are frequent frame rate drops while doing specific things. At the moment I wouldn't recommend it, but make sure to pick it up when these things are fixed.

reviewText:
1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

How many billionaires does it take to become a super hero?
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=574571885
Please note: The following review is written with the latest PC build in mind. Given that the initial release of Batman: Arkham Knight back in June last year was so catastrophic the publisher had to pull it from sale for six months I would not have recommended Arkham Knight back then unless it was heavily discounted and it would have been laced with some serious caveats to take into consideration. While technically the last few patches have gone to great lengths to stabilize the game - reports are that the game still suffers from audio glitches on certain systems as well freezing on some mechanical hard drives. Just to be on the safe side I installed the game on my SSD so I can't report about performance on mechanical HDD's so take that into consideration when purchasing. Also Arkham Knight does not (as far as I am aware) officially support cards in SLI or CROSSFIRE. Make sure you take this into consideration if you plan on running the game with either setup. While some players are reporting that it works fine, majority are saying that it doesn't so take heed.

For this review I ran the game on a MSI laptop with 16GB memory, 680M mobile GPU with 4GB video memory and i7-3630QM. As you can see I am running the game on a very outdated mobile chip and in order to maintain 30FPS I had to drop the resolution to 1600 x 900 with most of the settings disabled except for textures which I set to high. For the most part Arkham Knight ran perfectly fine at a stable 30FPS although driving around Gotham City in the batmobile or gliding around the city using your cape would often result in the game dropping to around 22-25FPS depending on the area. Given that I am running the game on a card way below minimum spec I suppose I can't complain too much.

Arkham Asylum was one of my favorite games from the previous generation (in fact it was my GOTY for 2009) so like many I was incredibly sad to hear Rocksteady announce during development that they would be moving away from the franchise once the game was completed (Edit: they did later hint that they may make another one in future) yet high with keen anticipation to dive into their final take on DC comics most famous Superhero, The Dark Knight. While the move to an open world setting hasn't exactly sat very well with me (I much preferred the tight focus Arkham Asylum employed that held players in a vice-like grip than the sprawling Arkham City where it was very easy to get caught up in all the games side quest busy work that I felt detracted from the games main narrative). If you chose to ignore all the padding - Arkham City was still a terrific adventure that helped solidify the franchises popularity. By the time Arkham Origins rolled around I was left feeling rather underwhelmed especially by Warner's copy and paste job that took all the things I didn't enjoy about Arkham City and amplified them. Arkham Origins was unfortunately also a buggy mess that still to this day suffers from some annoying bugs that got sidelined in favor of a DLC roll-out plan. Sadly it looks like Arkham Knight will be joining Arkham Origins when it comes to fixes vs DLC.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=545931725
Arkham Knight is once again at its strongest when you ignore the overabundance of meaningless altercations with the cities criminal underbelly, which sadly also includes far too many laborious altercations with an army of hostile mercenaries assembled by one of the games main villains, the Arkham Knight himself. The main story thread which centers around Batman trying to stop Scarecrow from deploying a viscous toxin that turns the cities residents into murderous thugs is in my opinion the strongest story of the entire Rocksteady franchise. The main plot is incredibly serpentine with a mystery-writers list of red herrings and shock surprises that definitely kept me on my toes eager to see how it would all eventually pan out. As a word of warning it's probably best you complete Arkham Asylum and Arkham City first as the story takes strong narrative ques from the first two games and is essentially an ending to the plotline that was initiated by Arkham Asylum. While not necessarily essential that you complete both adventures your enjoyment of the third and final act will be tempered by your knowledge of what transpired before and some may feel a bit lost at sea.

Gotham City also feels more like a city this time around although you won't bump into many city residents unless the game deems it to be so. Much like Arkham City (which featured a full city lock-down) this time most of the city residents have been shipped out of Gotham to avoid Scarecrows toxins. While it once again does feel oddly barren at times the city does feel more like a living breathing city when traversing the streets of Gotham in the batmobile which are littered with mercenary tanks and cars operated by gang members. While many have complained that the games vehicle sections are too frequent and annoying I quite enjoyed the change of pace they offered in terms of gameplay. If I do have one complaint, and its a big one, Batman's batmobile controls like a heavy duty crane performing Swan Lake on Ice. I think it mostly boils down to the actual controls of the batmobile itself, which are definitely odd to say the least, especially for a gamer like myself you loves Racing Sims and Arcade Racers. It definitely takes getting used to controlling the batmobile and I never particularly felt comfortable doing so. The game also introduces a series of obstacle courses, devised by The Riddler himself, which appart from not making much sense to begin with (like The Riddler would go out of his way to set up a series of underground race tracks for Batman) each course does gets progressively more difficult and frustrating given the vehicular controls. Unfortunately one of the games main side quests is tied to this silly game mechanic which I imagine most will endure because it involves saving Catwoman.

While I really enjoyed Arkham Knights main story line I was more than a little peeved that upon completion the game never truly ended. In order to get the games true ending, and I have no idea why the developers chose to go this route, you will need to complete every single side quest the game has to offer. This will initiate the Knightfall protocol but sadly most of these missions, such as clearing out various enemy factions, collecting Riddler trophies to finding trapped fireman are a tiresome chore that quite frankly I ditched once the main story reached its conclusion. Why Rocksteady did not leave all the collectible ♥♥♥♥ and mundane tasks for those who get enjoyment out of performing such things and make them optional is a questionable design choice since it forces players to complete things that I have come to hate about open world games and their collect-a-thon mentailty. I find this sort of stuff dreadfully dull and boring on a good day so when I am basically forced into it just to see the games true ending then it gets up my nose in all the wrong kind of ways.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=564806036
Arkham Knight definitely has many issues that once again stem from lackluster open world design which seems to plague most of these kinds of games epecially since Ubisoft started to churn them out by the dozen to the more obvious and glaring technical issues. If you are able to look past the initial disaster that was Arkham Knight then there is enjoyment to be had here. Just go in with a forgiving mind and you may be surprised.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying this review has nothing to do with the actual technical issues faced by somany PC players. Enough has been said about that. With that said:

So I buy Arkham Knight - I must admit fantastic game and i can run it ok by reducing the settings. I have a season pass too. Yay! Oh but theres issues with the PC version? So they pull it from the store. Fair enough. Months go by. I wait patiently for them to get going again so i can get some DLC and continue to enjoy the game. That time has come, except apparently my season pass only unlocks about 3 pieces of DLC, non of the new mini campaigns no new batmobiles, and not most of the skins. So can i get this straight WB, i assume my season pass covered the 'season' where you stopped releasing DLC and i am now expected to pay for it ON TOP of my season pass? I am furious!

I will never buy a WB game again (and to be fair, I've really enjoyed their recent ones, Arkham Knight included) due to these shoddy business practices, and cannot reccomend that anyone else does. Please people, dont encourage them.

edit - Thought I'd throw an edit to be fair to WB; They have fixed the season pass issue. Yay!! However I can't help but notice that although WB have now stated that for Windows 10 machines they recommend a minimum of 12GB RAM, they have not updated the min/recommended sys requirements on the store page. Despite the fact that, with Microsoft ramming Win10 down everyones throats, more and more people will be finding this issue out the hard way. I can only assume it's because if they were honest it would almost certainly stop a large percentage of steam users buying the game and if we know one thing, it's that WB loves that money.  So, unfortunately, one issue is fixed but many more remain. And shoddy business practice is still rampant. I still cannot reccomend this game and my views on future WB games remain unchanged.

edit 2: More shoddy business practices, just when i thought it couldnt get worse. The 'offer' they have made as COMPENSATION (although i imagine most affected already own most if not all of the Arkham games) is being used as a marketing technique to get more people to buy this broken game. They're advertising it on the store page as a Special Offer. Why not label it what it is. Poor compensation to the schmucks who bought the game. I must admit though, i was pleased to see that they are offering refunds. So one step forward, two steps back i guess.

No free DLCs or anything.
We were also promised that the console and retailer exclusive DLCs would be given for free to all Season Pass holders, but that was a lie too since some of them are still GameStop exclusive and PS4 exclusive.
Instead people who owned the game before re-release will be RANDOMLY given Arkham library games (Asylum, City, Origins and Blackgate, with no DLCs) and only directly into their library, so if someone already has them and hoped to gift the extras to friends, nope you don't get to do that.
You literally get jack s.h.i.t.
That's how Warner Jews decided to reward loyal fans of the franchise who bought every game in the series including Knight when it released.
By ramming a giant corporate c.o.c.k. up your a.r.s.e.

reviewText:
*Note: This relates to Batman: Arkham Knight as it stands on the day of it's release for PC.*

After editing .ini files to get this shoddy PC port to even function, I've managed to sink a couple of hours into the storyline of Arkham Knight. But I'm not going to talk about the story, the mechanics or even the gameplay.

As I said, I had to edit .ini files to get the game to *function.* As it stands, upon release, this game suffers from a locked framerate of 30, memory leaks, crashes, dropping frames, severe stuttering, *THE GAME DELETING ITSELF* and quite a few other severe problems. These issues are effecting the majority of people who purchased the PC version of this game to some degree or another, even on computers that are more than powerful enough to handle the Arkham Knight system requirements. It's effecting Nvidia and AMD users.

The port of this game is atrocious. It's barely playable at best and unplayable at worst. People shouldn't be unknowingly paying for unfinished, broken products. Hopefully a patch will be released soon to deal with these issues. In the mean time, we are out of luck. Enjoy your AAA video game title
date: crafted with love and care and held together with duct tape and prayers.""

reviewText:
I was one of the lucky, hated few for whom, on release, the game worked well for.

It had a few bugs but nothing terrible for me. At that time I would have given it an average to low review as it lacked polish and whilst playable it clearly had some major issues.

Since purchase -as I was fool enough to pick up the season pass with it- I  have been forced by the publisher to sit on my thumbs for months as they forcibly stopped me from accessing the DLC I paid for while they pulled the game which as a one off was a bitter pill but I suppose I could look forwards to them bringing it all out with a shiny. polished, as it should have been" version of the game.

Finally yesterday they re-released the game.....

Now the game crashes every 120 seconds in the batmobile
date: and around every 8 minutes on foot. The same graphical bugs
recommended:
low post processing quality and missing features (I'm looking at you fancy rain effects) are still there/missing after 4 months of "fixing". I am still effectively barred from accessing the dlc content I paid for months ago because now in essence the game for me is non-functional.

I am Extremely disappointed and feel let down by the whole debacle as such despite my best intentions I can personally only rate this game based on my experiences with it's playability which for me has lessened to the point that it is now unplayable.

I won't give it a straight 0/10 because some people might be able to get it to run
hoursPlayed: like I was when it first was released months ago.\n\n3/10 seems only fair to me. Franchise's legacy has been utterly ruined - for me at least."

reviewText:
Even after the update, I'm afraid I can't recommend this game.

It's saddening to think that despite the 5 month wait for the promised patch, I still can't play the game flawlessly as was promised. Ironically enough, I'm having a crashing issue that I didn't have when the game was originally released.


I can't play for more than 20 minutes without the game just abruptly crashing on me. I've tried everything from clearing registry files, rechecking file integrity of the game, to even deleting and re-downloading the game, but the issue still exists.

Warner Brothers, I'm done with you. Not only do you have the audacity to release a broken game, and fix it 5 months later, but you have the nerve to still charge the original price of the game and just add Batman games that are usually sold for a little less than $5 on sale as compensation, which I'm sure that most people that bought BAK already have. To top it all off, THE GAME IS STILL BROKEN....

AVOID LIKE THE PLAGUE.

reviewText:
Almost one month since its launch and no patch. Because releasing paid DLCs is more important than fixing your game, WB! Great job.

Amazing combat and really good, but a bit predictable story. The Batmobile, though, was the downfall of this game (apart from the hideous port). It was cool at start, but then it became a burden due to the fact that they push it down your throat on every segment that would be way better without it. ''Destroy some tanks. Destroy more drones...'' That's what you'll do for most of the game. They're not even hard; just plain boring. Boss battles are close to non-existent since most of them rely on the Batmobile...

Conclusion:

Game gets a 7/10 for its story and great combat, but tedious and burdening Batmobile sections. WB gets 0/10 for customer reliability.

reviewText:
This game is really mediocre . I'll try to be as synthetic as i can.

Positive aspects :

- The main story and  PERFECT ending were properly designed
- The Batmobile addition and the improved combat system
- The melee combat system is even more fluid and challenging
- No loadings when entering/leaving buildings
- Flying and diving were polished to the extreme perfection
- Gotham City is awesome

NEGATIVE ones ( spoilers included ) :

1 - pointless upgrade system  :

You'll have to spend several points in order to be able to unlock abilities,forcing you to wait a ♥♥♥♥♥ON of time before getting some of those 8-points abilities that are quite often meaningless, like the super-hyper batmobile's ejection system.

2 - some upgrades ARE STUPIDLY OVERPOWERED :

Clear example : you'll meet 2 new enemy types : medics and camouflaged soldiers. Don't worry,your jammer rifle will thwart their abilities,neutralizing them immediately.
NIO,JUST NO. A NEW ENEMY SHOULD RESULT IN AN IMPROVED THREAT / AND INCREASED GAME DIFFICULTY AND VARIETY. This is not the case at all,especially in New Game +.

3 - Lack of boss fights and overall boss stupidity :

You won't have boss fights. Forget about Bane,Coppehead,Deathstroke,Deadshot,Mr FREEZE.They're FFF GONE FOREVER. This is...stupid. Now. The Joker is dead,right? THEN ♥♥♥♥ING REPLACE HIS DEATH PROPERLY! New epic boss fights are totally absent,except for the Riddler's wresting match. ( --__-- ).

reviewText:
With great anticipation I unpacked my PC copy for Batman: Arkham Knight, however, the reign of my excitement was cut short by the quality of this product. To describe this product as substandard and bad would almost be to promote those terms to the level of respectability. To describe the PC portation as a piece of crap would be to run the risk of a discourse that would never again rise above the excremental. In short: It is one gigantic clusterf**k.

There may be people among you that ask me to give WB Games the benefit of a doubt and that they might not have known the state their game was in but that would suggest a complete loss of oversight and control which is just not realistic. I wish WB Games would have taken the same approach as with the Special Edition that was ultimately delayed because of quality issues. The fact that they haven’t leaves a bitter taste in the mouth of the PC community – appearance, apparently, is more important than a working software. The more we’re faced with such subpar programming the more I warm up to the idea that there should be a governing body; an equivalent to the NHTSA, NTSB or FDA.

I bet the executives over at Rocksteady, the name behind Batman: Arkham Knight, are fuming. See, Rocksteady wasn’t responsible for the PC port of this game but another third party was put in charge (various sources speak of Iron Galaxy) – yet, Rocksteady has all the bad press and is busy doing damage control; I feel for you guys! Maybe you should send some flowers to whoever signed off on this travesty. I wonder how you can sign off on a 5-disc physical copy of a videogame that installs exactly 7.7 GB and makes you download the remaining 26.1 GB from the internet – WHAT WERE YOU THINKING?! Whoever waved this through should have his decision power relegated to answer questions like whether you’d like fries with that burger.

How can you ship a game that has a framerate lock at 30?! Sadly, the problems won’t stop there – besides being slow and prone to stutter and locking up which topples the game over the brink of unplay-ability, you’re likely to suffer from audio glitches and then there is the god-awful Denuvo DRM, it’s as if there has been no lessons learned from Lords of the Fallen. Legitimate players are stifled and get hurt the most with those laughable protection attempts to fend off Pirates sailing the seven ISPs. I get that you want the community to purchase your games and you want to be compensated for your work – every gamer that actually cares for videogames understands that. The problem is that by treating everyone like a potential criminal and pumping out defective software you’ll lose your customer base, you’ll lose them by not taking them seriously and frankly you deserve it.

Arkham Knight is the absolute worst PC port I’ve ever seen. The only way to fix this is to have a fresh go at it, preferably not by the same company that is responsible for the initial portation but someone capable and competent. Instead I’m afraid we’ll just see a myriad of patches and nobody owning the mistakes that were made.

UPDATE: WB has pulled the game and suspended sales and already the masses are singing praise - the poor delusional souls. Commending WB to ‘a brave step’ or ‘the right thing’ is silly and wrong and is a perfect reflection of what’s wrong with gaming nowadays. You mustn’t sell defective goods, pulling it from sales is the normal thing to do and should therefore be acknowledged and met a with a slight nod but certainly not with exultation and cheer.
Many of us seem to have become so used to shoddy programming that we expect problems when we purchase a game, some even go as far as trying to gloss over game-breaking bugs. This will never bring about a change in behavior from the publisher, they’ll just expect us to bend over and ‘get on with it’ and worse, many are buying in to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, the broken promises and cheap tricks – it’s like they have the attention span of a gnat.
The fact is: This game should have NEVER been greenlit for PC release.

reviewText:
Great game; story and gameplay wise so far but the lack of AMD optimisation cripples performance, I'm using an R9 285 2GB on low textures and the game's fps lie between 21 and 30 and on average 27, note that there is a 30 fps cap in the actual game but not the game benchmark.
Why is the game so Nvidia biased?
I also pre-purchased the game (not from steam) before the game's minimum requirements were increased shortly before release date. I am using the updated graphics driver as well.
The game is quite fun though when its running smoothly, albeit uncommon, the batmobile is bloody awesome and it looks like there is so much to do.

Edit 1: There is a workaround for the 30 fps cap now. The game also runs terribly on Nvidea cards too.

Edit 2: I've set the max fps to 60 with the workaround and the game feels and runs better than before, the framerate no longer dips below 25 (except from extreme stuttering), I run the game mostly at 58-61 fps (keep in mind that my card is below the NEW altered minimum requirements that was posted shortly before the game's release and it runs at this framerate) however there are still many cases of stuttering and tearing occurs quite a lot.

Something I mentioned in the comments:
I said Nvidia biased because 2GB is the min for an Nvidea card whereas its is 3GB for an AMD card, also the HD 7950 3GB is a better performing card in most instances than the GTX 660 2GB.

Sidenote: I'm pretty sure the 7950 outperforms the 660 on Arkham City.

reviewText:
Batmobile™: Arkham Knight is the finale of Rocksteady's Batman series. The original title of this game was deliberately misleading in order to surprise fans when they discover the true protagonist of this game, the Batmobile. Drive around the stunningly beautiful Gotham City and take in the sights at a smooth 20FPS, all while blowing up unmanned APCs and blasting unarmed men with your taser. The gameplay is a mix between Twisted Metal and Burnout, you chase down cars, blast them with your cannons, then drive up walls. Gotham City has become so lawless even the laws of physics no longer apply. Team up with old foes and release plant spores all over the city, because your frame rate wasn't tanking hard enough.

Unfortunately the good also comes with the bad. Just when you thought you were free from the universally reviled fighting segments from the previous games, you get kicked out of the Batmobile occasionally and have to control Batman. Fight through waves of mindless goons and throw a few batarangs so you can progress to the next driving segment. On the bright side, the dreaded challenge maps from the previous games were removed and were instead replaced by racecourses so you can drive your cool car around some more.

The story contains the greatest twist out of all the Arkham games. You learn that Batman, the world's greatest detective, is unfathomably stupid. Watch as he discovers the blinking bomb shaped device in the road happens to actually be a bomb, and be drawn to the edge of your seat with anticipation as Batman tries to identify who the Arkham Knight is, because you probably figured it out immediately.

Overall I'd recommend this game to driving game enthusiasts everywhere and fans of Harley Quinn's massive assHOLYSHIT.

I know you've all looked, you can't lie to me.

reviewText:
The Joker: Dear friends... Today is the day that the Clown cried. And he cries not for the passing of one man, but for the death of a dream. The dream that he would someday taste the ultimate victory over his hated enemy. For it was the Batman who made me the happy soul I am today. How I agonized over the perfect way to thank him for that. Perhaps with a cyanide pie in the face. Or an exploding whoopie-cushion playfully planted in the Batmobile.

[Anger starts to creep into his tone as he looks at WB; everyone moves away from WB quickly]

The Joker:But those dreams were dashed by the weaselly little gunsel sitting there in our midst. The cowardly insignificant gonif who probably got lucky when Batman slipped on the slime trail this loser left behind him. This mound of diseased hyena filth who's not fit to lick the dirt from my spats...!

[regains composure]

The Joker:But I digress. The time for sorrow has passed. It's time to look to a future filled with smiles. And I'll be smiling again just as soon as we take that man THERE...

[points to WB]

The Joker:...and slap him in that box THERE...

[points to Batman: Arkham Knight]

The Joker:...and roll him into that vat of acid THERE!

[points to the Steam refund contact]

Warner Brothers: No! No! I didn't mean it!

[the Joker's henchmen grab him and stuff him into the coffin]

Warner Brothers: This isn't funny!

That is, what happened to Batman: Arkham Knight. Four months of waiting, and no result. The game is still crap, but I know that there is a good story and gameplay under that pile of lags. Never pre-ordering again, thank you.

Without Batman, crime has no punchline...

reviewText:
Still terrible. It seems the pc version of this game will never truly be fixed. If you're running a top-of-the-line system, you might find this playable (although that's not a guarantee) but otherwise you should stay away for performance reasons alone. Even if you get things running smoothly, it's still not a very good game.

The story is...fine. Incredibly predictable, but fine. If you've read even a few issues of Batman published within the last decade you're going to know exactly who the Arkham Knight is the moment you meet him. There's also just way too much going on. In addition to the core story missions, there is a glut of repeatable side missions that focus on different members of Batman's Rouges Gallery. The problem is that once you've played one kind of these missions, there's no reason to play any more of them except for completion's sake. All the penguin missions are identical, as are all the Two Face missions, as are all the ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t Riddler Races, etc, etc.

Which brings me to the biggest problem in this game, one you doubtlessly know about, the batmobile. It sucks. It's completely antithetical to what the rest of the game tries to offer, and it's forced upon you again and again. Why would anyone who enjoys the satisfying, rhythm-based combat or the puzzle-like, predator sections want to play Missile Command with tanks? It's boring and feels like a tax you're obliged to pay to access any of the fun stuff. It's also weirdly tied to the Arkham Knight, so it makes me resent his inclusion in the game even more. Wanna go fight Scarecrow's goons? Too bad, you gotta make it through 5 waves of Arkham Knight tank-faff first.

What's more, by being so watered-down the fun stuff isn't even that fun any more. The combat is pretty much the same that it's always been (although the few sections you get to team up with another member of the bat family, wherein you may execute cool team takedowns, are pretty fun), and there are so few predator sections (which were my favorite part of the series) that the game doesn't feel like it has room to experiment much with them.

Don't even get me started on the Riddler garbage (too late!). In Asylum, the Riddler stuff was essentially a bunch of fun extras that led to a really cool secret. City was a bit more ambitious but it was all fairly do-able. In Arkham Knight there are over 240 of those ♥♥♥♥ers, not to mention awful races where you'll blow up the batmobile umpteen times trying to memorize patterns in a lethal (yet somehow hideously dull) car-based version of Simon Says. And they use this ♥♥♥♥ to gate the real ending of the game. That's right, if you want the conclusion to this pile of dross you're going to have to sift through a whole lot of it.

In summary, Arkham Knight is a mess. Even without the technical issues, it's still an overstuffed game where all the good bits are suffocated under the sagging, bloated flesh of bad mechanics and repetitive design. Please don't buy it.
