reviewText:
While no doubt a controversial PC release, most, if not all, of the technical issues this game launched with have been well ironed out at this point. And outside of that I'd dare to say that Arkham Knight, while maybe not as exciting as previous titles in the series, is a great game.

As far as gameplay goes, the freeflow combat system is still an incredibly fun and satisfying gameplay system to battle with, and the predator encounters are still tense and engaging. But both of these systems lack the shine they once had when the series first began all those years ago due to general franchise fatigue. But I can't imagine any way to make any real groundbreaking improvments on either front.

The introduction of a playable batmobile seems to have been an attempt to battle this fatigue, and in some respects it succeeds. I found it exhilarating to race through the streets, chasing down enemies and completing races. But while they are fun at the start, on the whole the tank battles sections are not varied or complex enough to be very engaging. There is also an extremely dissappointing absence of interesting boss fights, which the series has lauded for in past titles. Almost every boss encounter is a slight variation of either the freeflow, predator, or tank battles systems.

The legendary setting of Gotham City has also never been more detailed and full of life though. And not only in any other game, but also any other medium. It is an absolute blast to glide around Gotham and appreciate all the care and detail that was put into its construction. But the lack of complex interior environments is a dissapointment.

The game's story is maybe its most impressive feat, and is anchored by a miriad of outstanding performances. The pacing is outstanding with each story beat being followed by an even better one. It has such an incredibly strong start, which it confidently builds on until the very end. Never before has there been such an enthralling narrative that successfully delves into Batman's mental and emotional psyche.

But with that being said, my biggest complaint (in terms of both the story and entire game) is that many iconic Batman villians are given a bit of the short stick in their side missions. Characters that have dense wonderful stories in the comics; like Hush, Deacon Blackfire, and Ra's al Ghul; are quickly and unceremoniously rushed out the door in an obvious attempt to ties up all the series' loose ends. And while I consider this a true travesty, I'll still confidently say that Batman Arkham Knight is a great game.

and even on the lowest settings its still a very pretty game.

Still going to keep my review as a "No" recommendation because its still very poor performance from such a big budget game. They spent more time making dlc then they did fixing their broken game. Do not support this game.

=========
Story:

About the Arkham Knight character being "an entirely new character". That is a lie. Its an old character. False advertising.

Thomas Wayne narrated a trailer. He is not in the game in any form. Just an FYI in case you got your hopes up about hearing more from him.

If they had just done the "Arkham Knight" like he was in the comics

commentsCount: then it would have worked a hell of a lot better as a trilogy ending. I still would have known what was coming
column16:
but at least it would have been set up better.

=========
Gameplay:

The batmobile starts out pretty neat
column17: but the game forces you to tank fight in it WAY too much
column18: especially in the latter half of the game. And not only that but the tank combat rarely ever changes
column19: the minor additions to the combat do nothing to change it up and it becomes a chore every time you hear someone on the comm say tanks incoming.\n\nSome of the puzzles where you have to work with your remote controlled batmobile are neat
column20: but then the game forces you to use the batmobile for a majority of the puzzles and it gets tiresome.\n\nPredator takedowns (I think thats what they were called) are awesome to look at
column21: but somewhat exploitable if you're half decent at stealth takedowns. And once you upgrade it you can pretty much clear an entire area without even trying. Low risk
column22:
high reward gameplay.

=========
TL:DR

If you can ignore the performance issues
column24: and slog through all the tank combat
column25:
then you'll find an average Batman Arkham game.

If it ran perfectly I'd probably give it a 7/10.
But because it runs so poorly I give it a 4/10"

reviewText:
Cannot recommend this game after the botched launch and failure to patch.

The game has now been 're-released', tagging all prior reviews as 'pre-release' in an attempt to invalidate negative reviews (The game was around ~40% positive at 're-release', which is almost unheard of), despite the fact that the game was very much released and only pulled after public outcry.

Many of the performance issues have NOT been fixed as promised. There is a fairly serious memory leak, and their 'fix' was to tell users 'we’ve found that having at least 12GB of system RAM on a PC allows the game to operate without paging and provides a smoother gameplay experience.' (Windows 10), or 'If you encounter this, simply re-launching the game will resolve the issue.' (Windows 7). Other FPS issues, such as severe rain/batmobile slowdown as well as very clear object pop-in, are still present.

WB has issued an 'apology' in the form of free past-Arkham games, but most of the people affected, who bought the game at original launch, or pre-purchased, already own these prior games, as they are fans of the series. It seems more of a simple promotional tool to pull in more new buyers (The 'apology' free pack is for anyone who buys the game for the next couple weeks, in addition to the past), rather than actually compensating those who were affected. New buyers actually get all the same content as pre-purchasers and original launch buyers, while also benefitting from a $10 reduced price.

Performance aside, if you're lucky and have the game run well on your machine (it seems to be left to chance whether the game works well or not on any system, high or low end) the game itself is actually very well done and fun. Most of the characters, with the exception of the main antagonist (whose identity is made painfully obvious WELL before the reveal), are written and voiced well, and the different side objectives are mostly fun. The combat is fluid, as you'd expect coming from any of the past games. However, it doesn't add too many new elements. The one big new 'feature' is the batmobile, which should be a fun addition, but is shoehorned into any situation the writers could think of, and turns out to be very boring to use.

EDIT: Oh, forgot to mention. One of the optional boss battles, with the Riddler, is locked behind obtaining ***every riddler trophy in the game***. Basically, you do his side questline, which was actually pretty enjoyable, win, and he says 'well, you haven't won until you do ALL my challenges, peace!' and runs away. As someone that likes doing side missions and completing side-arcs, this really bugs me. I'm not willing to run around for hours and hours doing boring little puzzles and 100% the game just to get to a new peice of content/arc closure. I gave up and just watched it on Youtube.

===================================================================

All in all, with the performance issues, horribly handled launch, poor community support and self-serving 'apology', I can't recommend this game at anywhere near $50. Even if you buy it with a good rig, it seems to be a 50-50 shot whether or not you'll have performance issues that hinder your play. The actual gameplay and story is fun though, so it may be worth taking a risk (or 'demoing' it to test performance, then buying) once it goes on sale for $10-$15.

I'd love to give this game a good review, because the small amount of actual gameplay I've seen has been good thus far. I can't, though. Performance is horrendeous! I have a Titan X paired with an i7 5930K and 32GB DDR4 RAM. After fiddling with the setting:

At Max settings: It has a baseline of 60FPS, but with erratic dips into as low as the 30s for no apparent reason while gliding and even worse drops at Batmobile sequences. GPU usage hovers around 65%.

At the LOWEST settings: And this is where I get angry, the SAME thing. Baseline of 60FPS with the SAME s♥♥♥♥♥tic drops. GPU usage hovers around 50%.

What that tells me is that the devs actually succeeded in screwing up the implementation of the very stable Unreal Engine. If console performance is good, then it proves that they gave NO THOUGHT to PC gamers and just did a barebones port with no optimization. And if the console performance is also bad, then the developer just sucks, period.

Even the way they went about realizing that there were very serious AMD performance issues: It's like someone on the Dev team booted up the game on launch day on their home computer with an AMD card and went: Oh my God

And now anyone who pre-orders the final version, gets all that too!... So wheres the customer loyalty bonus for those of us that stuck out the midn bogglingy bad mess this game was?
basically a big middle finger, a thanks for bug testing our game, now buy more things from us...

I'd recommend the game itself, but not this company. Not after this PR disaster.

reviewText:
I wish I could be the batman on release date.
Brand New Nvidia 960 w/ new drivers
3.2 ghz i5 CPU
16 gb of Ram
Basically way past minimum and mostly past recomended and I could only play past the poison ivy part and introduction to batmobile combat before getting tired of the constant stuttering and inability to even watch cutscenes because it freezes all of the time. Rocksteady better be releasing that patch in a couple of days.

This isn't to say the game is bad, but if I can't play the game at all then obviously it has issues that need to be fixed before it gets the review it deserves rather than the one it gets

Edit: Still no luck to getting it running smoothly. Been told that the pre-load files may have had something wrong and am currently redownloading. Only problem is for some reason I am only getting around 200 kb/s right now on steam while downloading from other sources is just fine (3 mb/s)

2nd and possibly final edit until optimization patch comes out: I am now able to play with everything on the lowest settings and it still suffers from frame rate drops, small amounts of stuttering and audio desyncs during conversations and cut scenes. Other than these known issue it is a very good game. The story and side missions come rather naturally in most cases and the riddler is back to actually giving some riddles rather than small puzzles. The story is great so far with something that throws me completely off guard often. I loved Arkham City and Asylum and this game by far takes the cake for me. I will recommend this game only after the optimization fixes.
The heat coming from my computer when playing this game right now also causes my room to become unbearably hot.
And the latest issue is randomly the game will seem to alt-tab and whenever I try to re enter it crashes. Only happened twice now within the 7 hour time frame that I have been playing. Minor nuisance since the game autosaves a lot.

Honestly it has been too long without another update and the first one still hasn't fixed the terrible preformance.

Pros:

The game itself is very fun. The batmobile is a great part of the game that helps with puzzles and overall is just a fun way to get around the city. Combat has been expanded with new enemies and the ability to pick up and use weapons. The one thing that will never make sense is why Batman must go out of his way to show boat when he picks up a weapon. He stands there for an extra 3 seconds flipping a bat instead of hitting people with it. The main story was amazing with a twist around the corner everywhere.

Cons:

Except for the Arkham Knight. That was the worst identity and was obvious who it was from the start (If you are a big Batman fan). Side quests are boring and repetitive. Looking around a alrge city for dead people was fun. Chasing Firefly in the batmobile each and every time was repetetive. Chasing cars for a while and following them to a stash was boring. Finding a mysterious creature and curing it was boring. They were all practically the same. Remember in Arkham City when the bosses were fun too? You don't get that in this game. Come to think of it, there wasn't actually any bosses. The Arkham Knight should have been a great boss fight, but it wasn't at all. It seems like every boss fight in this game either comes down to chasing them all over the place and taking them down or dealing with a bunch of adds and henchmen without actually fighting the boss.
Batmobile combat is less than stellar. Shoot unmanned tanks and shoot more tnaks. There are tanks everywhere. Often times it will be 50 to 1 and you have to take them all. Often times I am frustrated by the batmobile combat because there is so much ♥♥♥♥ to watch out for and just isn't fun.

Ultimately I wanted to like this game. I just can't when the entire game feels like Rocksteady didn't make it except for the story. Along with the fact that it still has not really had any fixes to issues like the stuttering framerate. Yes the game runs. But it also crashes and stutters every now and then.

I can not reccomend this game at full price even if they fixed every single optimisation issue. The game is just missing fun bosses, new gadgets, and the only thing really holding the game up is the story.

If you really want the game just wait for the GOTY edition at like 20 dollars. IF it gets GOTY I guess

reviewText:
Welcome to the horrible future of gaming. As usual, games are still being shipped broken/unoptimized. The 2nd video game crash since before the NES is coming.
You all heard it here folks.

Dogs and cats living together, mass hysteria.

I'm running current drivers for GTX 970 and there is still stuttering. If you change the fps lock from 30 fps, the stuttering worsens. This feels like a watered down console port. Made to sate the egotistical console gamers and give them the satisfaction of having the superior" version of the game.

Wait a few days from release date or until they can patch the game and fix it.

What makes this even more of a spit in the face of PC players is that the devs ask us to tone down our graphics settings so that their crap game can look even crappier while running less crappy.

No quality control for a PC port that was advertised as being the best on an Nvidia machine. People pre-ordered this game for $60 and payed over $100 for a "premium" season pass bundle. The game is broken on release. Sickening."

reviewText:
Pros:
Great story and twists.
Lots of stuff like challenges / collectibles and places to visit, to keep you busy for quite a few days.
Great combat system, which let you chain up attacks as long as you want.
A big range of gear upgrades available to help you to take up on Gotham best criminals challenges.

Cons:
Performance issues, i had the game constantly reaching only 40-50fps with some casual stuttering.
Casual stuttering and texture pop-ins.
Game will never be fully fixed
Have you purchased this game ? Don't own the previous episodes of the series ? You're going to get them for free.
http://steamcommunity.com/games/208650/announcements/detail/128710596358664118
If you already own them, you get nothing.

Game will never be fully fixed, and refunds are being offered.
http://steamcommunity.com/games/208650/announcements/detail/128710596369779495

Here's a much more detailed
http://www.pcgamer.com/batman-arkham-knight-is-back-on-steam-but-still-not-fully-fixed/

So, do yourself a favour, and only purchase this game during a super sale, or only if you are sure your rig will manage to play it without issues, or simply hope to be one of the lucky chosen.

reviewText:
It's not a bad game. I beat it 100% and I'm playing NG+ at the moment. It has flaws (boss fights, underused villains, battank) but Batman's gameplay, gadgets, and combat animations are some of the best in the series.

But this doesn't mean anything if you can't play the game. And most people still can't. After waiting months for a re-release. And with nothing to show for it but the other Arkham games, which most people own anyway (seriously, who would pre-purchase Knight if they hadn't played the others!?!). Plus the DLC which just got released is so far underwhelming, and was not worth the wait for those of us who (by some miracle) could play this game at launch.

Duck WB for this whole disaster. Don't buy this game. It's worth a cheeky play though.

reviewText: So here is an update. After getting really bad performance using a 780ti sli rig, i decided to disable sli and try benchmark the game with a single card which got me much better performance then the two. after editing the ini file I managed to hit 60 fps on max settings apart from gameworks (yay) However this is where the problems started coming in. As i loaded up the story, I started gliding around and noticed huge fps drops and stuttering. I lowered the settings bit by bit to the point where i was set to the lowest settings but was still getting stutters. In combat I got 50 - 60 fps which is great but too bad it isn't consistant throughout. I really was looking forward to playing this game for a long time but the drops are making this game unplayable right now, really disappointed but hopefully patches come at CDPR speed

reviewText: Awful performance. First the game is locked to 30 fps by default. Despite Nvidia's website saying it supports SLI, I get absolutely no usage on my second card, unless I dedicate it to PhysX and the performance is still abysmal. There is a serious lack of graphical options, leaving you with texture quality (low and normal), AA (on or off), level of detail (low, normal and high), shadow quality (low, normal and high), and Gameworks options. It seems to completely break RTSS overlay across the numerous games I've tried to use it with, requireing a restart to fix.\n\nGlad I played $30 for the Premium Edition" including the season pass from a reseller. Although refunding it would have been a better option. Seriously WTF Rocksteady? I was just bragging about how I trusted you guys

reviewText:
Neither Warner Bros., Rocksteady, or Iron Galaxy Studios deserve your money for this half attempted port which released with tons of issues. Took months to fix and the entire time nothing was done to make things right with the PC community, just thanks for being patient in a situation where players had no choice but to either hang tight or get a refund.

Go watch some Youtube videos of people playing the game to get the best it has to offer without any of the pain as Rocksteady loses their way by overpromising and discovering just how hard it is to deliver on those promises. Get ready to experience the Bat-tank, a wannabe Batmobile that plays more like it belongs in Armored Core than a Batman game and will leave you wondering how on Earth Batman avoids killing people while running them over in a two ton vehicle doing 90 mph. Watch as characters are marginalized to pointless side missions which feel like a reason to implement some weird puzzle mechanic or to merely make things so easy there isn't even a challenge anymore. Watch in awe as Rocksteady disregards their own story timeline and simply throws characters in where they don't belong because they already built that character model so who cares if we got the wrong Robin? Prepare yourself to be underwhelmed by every piece of DLC content that is not only overpriced but underdeveloped as skins look worse than they did last generation, new characters can't be used in free roam mode, and story content that leaves you scratching your head as to when any of this is supposed to take place.

This is how they did it. This is how they killed the Batman.

Good job Warner Bros., Rocksteady, and Iron Galaxy Studios for taking what should have been a surefire hit and doing nearly everything possible short of coming to my home and punching me in the gut right after I booted the game up to ensure this was a miserable experience. Save yourself even those couple of bucks you're thinking of spending on this because it's already heavily discounted because they lost a ton of money on this port. There are far better games to play than this and far better developers who will actually deliver a functioning game when promised without compromising their vision to make sure the console version is working and the graphics are as pretty as possible with gameplay coming second. There are times where even the voice actors are phoning it in because they could tell how ridiculous this was. Spoiler alert this game contains the most unconvincing death scene ever that leaves you wondering when a 12 year old took over writing duties and why the cast seems more interested in delivering as few words or emotion as possible before moving on like it never happened.

reviewText:
I installed this game for the first time on June 2, 2015 on a laptop with a mobile Nvidia 970M graphics card and an Intel I7 3.0 ghz processor with 16 gig. of RAM; the screen flashed on and off in a way that would cause an epileptic fit in a healthy person then promptly crashed to the desktop. Now 4 MONTHS! later I install the game this evening after the relaunch" of the game (ostensibly to negate all the previous negative reviews) and after double clicking on the games icon the screen starts strobing on and off like a poor mans Christmas tree and stays that way until I am able to select "borderless windowed" mode from the game options (no small feat since I can barely see the screen!)

Oh and the framerates still dip well below 60 fps in most action sequences.

Rocksteady......   SHAME!

WB Games........  SHAME!

Subcontracted crap PC porter...   SHAME!

reviewText:
TLDR; 7/10 game running at a 3/10 performance. Game runs poorly, actual story is okay but ruined in the last hour, extra collectables were a chore and not worth the time and effort. Buy GOTY edition for cheap but the game still isn't good enough on PC. I will update this review with future patches.

Please note, I have played Arkham Asylum and City both to 100% on PC/xbox 360. I have also played origins but did not 100% the main. This review will not contain any spoilers. I played at 1080 resolution at around 60/45fps with very occasional dips lower, with the lowest settings for everything. I have an i7 4770k, 16gb RAM and a GTX 770 and I played this on windows 8. I played the game on a SSD so loading times might be considerably better for me than the files on a HDD. When I played the game, I had the interim patch but from what I understand, the full release hasn't changed much. Also, I played the game with a wired xbox 360 controller on a 1080 TV on hard mode. Your experience may differ based on your hardware and software. Also I will not be including a full dlc review in this.

Performance/appearance:

Batman Arkham knight ran poorly on my machine. There was issues concerning large frame rate drops about (20-30 fps decrease), textures not loading for a few seconds, micro stuttering and large loading times. The performance is unacceptably bad for a game in 2015 with a major publisher backing the studio. The patches have improved the performance however, it is still not good enough for most gamers. You shouldn't be required to have a SSD, over 8 GB RAM and a 760+ for a performance this bad. I suspect more patches will be added in the future to improve the performance so if you want an update of the performance based on my parts in the future then send me a mail and I will see if things have improved.
Batmobile sections were the biggest offenders of reducing the frame rate however the frame rate dropped at random during other portions of the game.
I will say, the game was nice to look at with some cool destructions physics, lighting effects some excellent rain effects. If you are using an nvidia card the nvidia gameworks options look nice but they completely crippled my frame rate to around 22-18 fps. I'm not sure what the effect will be on an AMD card but I imagine it will probably make things even worse for your experience.

Gameplay:
Gameplay is broken up into a few different sections. These include combat, stealth, free roam, driving the batmobile and small detective section. These mechanics are used in part with the side missions and the main campaign. If you have played any of the Arkham games you know how the combat is and the free roaming however there has been minor changes which did make a difference to my experience with the game.

Combat was much less precise than in Asylum or City. I found myself hitting enemies who I was not aiming for more than a few times which lead to some unfair deaths. My partner and a friend played the PS4 version and we found the same issue with their experience too. Some of the new enemies aloud for healing and revival which combined with existing enemies, meant combat lasted far too long in some sections. However, as a Batman veteran, the game was a nice challenge with the combat and it was nice for hard mode to actually feel like it was hard at times.

Stealth is for the most part unchanged. You distract enemies, you knock them out, you pick them up one by one and you which if you have played any of the previous games you know the song and dance. There are some minor changes but they don't change too much bar getting the fear multi takedown ability which makes many of the stealth sections much easier. In response, enemies have new gadgets and tech but it is given at a nice difficulty curve.

Freeroaming was probably the least changed mechanic but the most improved. The grappling hook has received a much welcomed boost in strength and you can go much further and faster than in previous games. I did have some issues with the frame rate during some of the very fast flight sections however they were not too frequent. The only down side to freely roaming the city is some sections will require you to use the batmobile. Which leads me to my next point.

The batmobile was the worst bit of the game and unfortunately you have to spend a lot of time in it. As I mentioned in my performance paragraph, I found the frame rate was at its worst during these sections with the frame rate dropping significantly when driving very quickly. The batmobile is also used in stealth section in some ridiculous ways and many times during the game when i didn't know what to do, the solution as using the batmobile in some silly way. I get that this is a game and I should suspend my disbelief but I also didn't have much fun during these sections due to the dull tank controls, low frame rate and at the rate I had to use it.

Detective mode has probably been one of the smallest but most significant changes for Arkham Knight. The main detective vision has been seriously nerfed giving less detail on objects, being blocked more often in stealth sections, not available in the batmobile and having a lower viewer distance. For most of the game this isn't an issue, however I will explain why it is an issue with the side missions.

There are some decent side missions but some of the supervillains were pretty lame and their side missions were tedious with the same mission repeated several times. If you aren't going to try and get all the riddles then move onto my story section. If you have played any of the previous games then you will know about the riddler mission which involves collecting question mark tokens and taking pictures of question marks and small hints of characters from the batman universe. As I mentioned in detective mode, the vision mode has been hugely nerfed and now riddler clues are not highlighted at all. This means you are almost forced to go find all the riddler informants and constantly check you map which can be a chore at best and a miserable slog at worse.

Story:
As I mentioned, I won't be spoiling the game. I felt the Arkham Knight was a little underwhelming but it was to be expected. I would recommend avoiding IMDB pages and looking up voice actors if you don't want to know who the Arkham Knight. However, the identity was pretty obvious about 50% through the story. Parts of the best bits of the story are literally there to develop the reveal or the Arkham Knight and was some brilliant depictions of some of the iconic sections of the batman lore.
There was a complaint I had that one of the best bits of the game and some of the story arcs of one of the characters was made completely pointlessly in the last reveal. This was a disappointment to me as it was one of the best bits of the game and probably the single most shocking part in any of the Arkham games.
Overall, the story was the only thing keeping me going and I found once I was done with the story, the fun I had with the game was diminished and I was getting impatient with the side missions. If you are compelled to collect everything like I was then go for it but if I were to do it for a first time again, finish all the side missions except the riddler and then watch the true ending on YouTube.

Please let me know if I have missed anything and I can update my review to reflect my opinion on the sections I have missed.

reviewText:
If you overlook disasterous release of Batman™: Arkham Knight it's a well elaborated game with amazing graphics.
Arkham Knight brings large rigorous open world, Batmobile and with it the whole new system of drone fights. Speaking about Batmobile for one thing it's sad when drone fights become annoying when the game forces you to crush an army of them for hundered times over and over. On the other hand driving Batmobile through Gotham streets or on one of many race tracks the game offers is pretty enjoyable. It was for the first time I found Arkham challenges entertaining.

Predator mode is terrific as always, including more features than before, new types of enemies and also gadgets. This is what developers did really great work with. However what I think is not done with great care or I could say was sloppily made is the story. Many think the story is the best part of the Arkham series, but in this title its predictable, rapidly escalating and not going too far. Best part of it are cutscenes which are joy to behold.

Altogether I recommend this one if you have played previous titles.

7.5 /10

reviewText:
(Writing this late cause my old computer wasnt able to run it)

Wow! I must say as a massive fan of Batman and the Arkham games (Apart from Origins) this is the true epitome of Batman lore. Nothing comes close as it pays homage to so many great characters, In detail I havent seen before! Nothing immerses me as much as a video game does, This is one of the reasons Batman: Arkham Knight is so great (and why I love video games so much :) ).

Exploring Gotham is a treat gliding or driving the Batmobile, Announcements pop up from all over and the game constantly engages you to search all around the city. Each Villian has there own feel and interesting story to go with. There are many twists in the game which im sure would have more effect on me if i didnt already know what was going to happen ;) (Massive Batman nerd here), But the way they're revealed is great and enjoyable. The combat is great as always maybe a bit stale now, But this is the final batman game so its been well used and not overdone.

There is so much i want to talk about, but it is hard to without spoiling the story and i hate when reviewers do that. I will just say this is the greatest portrayal of the Batman Universe to date and would recommend it to anyone even remotely interested in Batman, i know theres alot of fans out there but still... im really bad at ending this so im just gonna say GO BUY BATMANSSSSSS!!!!

reviewText:
Against my better judgement I preordered the game because the previous titles in the series all worked very well at launch. What can I say, it's kind of a letdown.

I've played for an hour so far and the game itself is probably good.  The combat is fun as always and in contrast to a lot of other people I find the whole Batmobile gameplay quiet appealing so far.

That being said, the performance and optimization of this game is a huge bummer.
Arguably I don't have the best rig there is, but while I can play The Witcher 3 on high settings without any problems, Arkham Knight's performance is just awful.
There are constant fps drops which really disturb the flow of the game and lowering the graphics settings doesn't really do that much, despite making the game look much worse than Arkham Asylum.

On top of that, there aren't even that many settings to begin with ingame. You actually have to meddle with an .ini file to change things like Motion Blur or Depth of Field, settings that SHOULD be easily accessable through the menu.
YES, you can change these options (which for some people will crash the game on startup, so good luck with that, I guess), BUT this still doesn't excuse the lack of a proper ingame menu to change them. It's Dying Light all over again.

So let's hope there will soon be some patches to the performance as well as to the possibilities of configuration. In it's current state, the game is, at least for me, not fun to play.

Another point of criticism is the magnificently intransparent DLC policy coming with this game. I preordered it and according to my vendor's advertisement I SHOULD have the Harley Quinn DLC....well...like many others I don't, and nobody really seems to know why.
What I read on forums went from it being Gamestop exclusive to having been pulled by Rocksteady from the preorder last minute and now being avaiable through the Season Pass, which would quiet frankly be beyond devious.

So all in all, it is a pretty messed up launch and I strongly recommend AGAINST buying it at this point, at least not for full price. I actually got it cheaper and I still am rather annoyed.

reviewText:
This review is updated and based off the version after the September 3ed patch
So while this game has had a hard first few months, it finally got its patch. With this new patch, preformance was increased, the 30 fps cap is now an optional setting in graphics tab, and stuttering is minimum if you set settings to ones that match your PC build (but still consistant). Now to the breakdown.

Gameplay
+The characters, enemies and allies, are very well designed and voiced
+This Batman game adds many new mechanics listed below
+Batmobile/vehicle's make for awesome gameplay
+New enemies, from Medics that revive enemies to brutes weilding Miniguns
+New abilites, such as the Fear Takedown and Counter-throw
+Have a helper during combat, for new items/abilities and duel takedowns
+The map is large, filled with enemies and interesting side-quest
+The AI is more adaptive with the Militia, such as radio checkins, seeing into and grenading vents, and drones
+Selecting side-quest is a breeze with the new mission select wheel
+The game is just amazingly beutiful

-The game seems to lag more during batmobile chases, prefer to roam by glide to reduce lag
-The game still lags a lot, and stuttering still occures
-As far as I've seen so far, you cannot switch characters (i.e. Robin, Nightwing) outside of their missions, making them one-time characters, making their unique weapon-loadout pointless
-PC controls are terrible, either adapt or use a consol controller PC adapter like I use
-Some side-quest are very short, and makes me wishing they would make them longer

Story (Warning, May Contain Slight Spoilers
+The story was decently long, and interesting
+Scarecrow and the Arkham Knight made great main-enemies
+The Arkham Knight is a well-design character, personality and preformance wise
+Has a good few twist in the story

-One detective-mode crimescene in the entire main story, and a few mini-detective-mode crimescene's in sidequest. Wtf WB Games? They were one of the funnest parts!!!
-Has a pretty obvious twist if you're a fan of Batman, knowing the comicbooks

Overall
The game was very enjoyable to play overall. However, one feature that I really enjoyed from previous Arkham games, the Detective Crime scanes were lacking, very disappointed by this. The Batmobile made a heavy impact on the game, in both quest and campaign, making up for lack of detective work. This is, what I believe, to be a great ending to the Batman: Arkham series, however with WB games taking its sweet time releasing the patch, I feel like the PC version is dead and unrevivable.

EDIT: With the refund option now avalible for everyone, no matter the hours played, I would recommend to refund the game for PC. While I do not recommend the game for PC, I do recommend the game for console if avalible.

reviewText:
Batman Arkham Knight is an action-adventure game developed by Rocksteady Studios and published by Warner Brothers, coming out on PS4, Xbox One and PC in June 2015.  The game is run using the Unreal Engine 3. The PC release of Arkham Knight brought plenty of controversy and issues.  The technical issues on the PC release almost forced Warner Brothers to suspend sales on the game in order for them to address the issues people were having. The game was re-released on Steam in October 2015 after a few patches in order to solve the technical issues.  Sadly people still reported problems with the game forcing Warner Brothers to offer full refunds on the game regardless of whether you met the regular criteria or not.  To this day, the developers are still working on technical issues which people are having.

Before I start my review, I would like to point out that I played this game on a mechanical hard drive, with one nVidia 970 (my second one is being RMA’ed right now!), playing at 1080p with graphics turned on and the majority of the nVidia graphics options turned on as well.  On launch of the title, Warner Brothers recommended that the game be installed on a solid state drive, so as you read the review, please bear all of the above in mind.

Game play in Arkham Knight is again, the same as its predecessors; this shouldn’t be taken as a negative thing though, as the game play is absolutely stellar. The combat system is as fluid and easy to grasp as ever, with some new and interesting combos and special take downs being introduced, such as double take downs when you are working with a partner on some missions.  Some new gadgets have been introduced, a remote controlled batarang which can scan the area for information, and a voice synthesiser, that mimics other character’s voices; this gives you plenty of different ways to use such as ordering enemies around and opening voice controlled locked doors.
The major new game play mechanic that has been added in Arkham Knight is the Batmobile.  You are able to summon the Batmobile to your location when you are on foot or gliding in the air. The Batmobile has two different mods that can easily be used at any time: Pursuit and Battle. Pursuit is the regular movement mode with little on offer in terms of firepower, as you are traveling from A to B. Battle mod turns your Batmobile into a death machine; as you utilise all of the weapon systems on board. The Batmobile can be upgraded using the points you are rewarded with for levelling up as well.

Graphically, I was really impressed with how the game looked. The high resolution textures and rain effects are all stunning.  All of the characters look almost life like, and you can really appreciate this when you get close up shots on their faces; so much detail has gone into the modelling and texturing, to the point where you can see the blackheads on the Joker’s face! All of the game’s animations are done very well too; the Arkham combat system has a very fluid feel to it, so they need to be spot on or else it would just look out of place.

The plot within Arkham Knight is probably my favourite of the series so far. It is the last episode in the Arkham series, so takes place after origins, Asylum and City. I have not read the comic book series so I missed out on a lot of the plot in between the games but the game does do a good job of trying to fill in the gaps.  Arkham Knight introduces a few new main characters to the fold if you haven’t read the comic books too, such as Robin, and a more starring role for Barbara Gordon. With plenty of the other regulars returning, such as Cat-Woman and Alfred. You will encounter plenty of the super villains, Scarecrow, Penguin, Two-Face, Riddler, Poison Ivy, Harley Quin, and of course, the Joker. One new villain, Arkham Knight also has a starring role and has an important storyline plot attached to him as well.

Difficulty can be scaled depending on how hard you set the game. I felt the medium setting to be just enough challenge without hitting the brick wall. None of the boss battles in Arkham Knight are just generic fist fights, each of them uses a unique mechanic which adds some variety to the game.

As with its predecessors’ the open world aspect of the game does a very good job of filling in lots of “blank space” with plenty of side missions and collectables to find. Most Wanted missions, Riddler's Revenge, collectables and AR challenges makes the optional part of the game full to the brim with content. You are also able to unlock different endings to the game by completing the side missions as well, giving you more incentive to continue playing after finishing.

I have been playing for about twenty five hours so far, this has allowed me to finish a handful of side missions and the main story in the game. I will definitely be dropping a few more hours into completing the rest of the most wanted missions in order to unlock the alternative endings, but I can’t see myself wanting to collect the hundreds of Riddler items again after my fiasco with the past two games with them!

Now, onto the technical issues.  As I said above, I am using a single nVidia 970 and the game was installed on a mechanical hard drive. The majority of the time the game was running around 57-60 fps. There are moments where the frame rate will drop to 30 for no good reason. I can understand if it drops on more graphically intensive scenes or when there is a lot happening, but it can sometimes happen when you are in a building with very little going on. Maybe this would have been different if I was using SLI, but even then, it has been reported the SLI makes no difference to the performance. Taking all of this into consideration it seems I was on the lucky side and the pure power in my machine seemed to pull it through to an acceptable playable state.

My conclusion of Batman Arkham Knight may come as a controversial one, but like all of my reviews it is my honest and truthful opinion. I am going to highly recommend Arkham Knight. The game play and interesting compelling story make it a definite worthwhile play through.  I would only recommend this game to people who have a bit of meat in their rig to play it though, unless you are willing to sacrifice some of the graphical fidelity, please bear in mind all of what I noted in the technical issues section of the review and make your judgement on purchasing the game on that if you are on the fence. The game’s retail price on Steam is £34,99, I would also recommend that you don’t purchase it for that price, either get it from another source (definitely not GEE 2 AAAA hint hint hint hint) or wait for one of Steam’s sales as this game will go on sale for less than £20, and more than likely even more now.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here.

reviewText:
I waited patiently for four months for Rocksteady and Warner Bros. to put this game back on Steam and fix it properly. I bought it when it was first up for sale, and the game ran very poorly for me, yet I wanted to know where the story went so I struggled through all the lag and stuttering and horrible textures to play through it to the end of the main story. I only own a PC and not any consoles so that was the only choice available to me to play through the game. I was really excited to play the sequel to Arkham Asylum and City, two games that I really enjoyed, and I am a huge Batman fan. I read all the comic books, and I watch all the movies and cartoons, so I was always going to play through this game, awful port or not.

Now I will admit I don't have the best and most up to date computer in the world, but I find it more than adequate to play through pretty much any other game I might try to throw at it. I've enjoyed playing The Witcher 3, GTA V, MGS V and countless other great games on it this year with perfectly acceptable settings and stable performance. But somehow this game just won't quite run nicely for me, even after the update from a month or two ago, which did improve things for me and make the game run a fair bit better, it's still not quite right. The framerate jumps up and down like a yo-yo, from around 55fps to 25fps, constantly shifting. I'd prefer the game to run at a consistent 60fps but I honestly don't mind a framerate in the 30 range, but only if it's stable and consistent, but it is not in this game no matter what settings I put it on. It's kind of like watching a movie and somebody is constantly pressing the fast forward and pause button. The textures, which I have to play on 'low' as I have a 2gb VRAM card, have improved from the awful state of release, but I still see occasional objects that just look like a blurry mess. There's also still issues with dialogue going out of sync on cut scenes.

What annoys me here is that this is a game running on Unreal Engine 3, a game engine that has been around for over a decade and developers really have no excuse for not being able to develop stable and well optimised games on it at this stage. I understand that it is a 'heavily modified' version of Unreal Engine 3, but it really shouldn't matter. And it most certainly should not be an engine that requires amazing hardware to handle a game developed on it. I believe Bioshock Infinite runs on UE3 and I run that game at like a stable 80fps with everything on max settings, different type of game admittedly, but really there is no excuse.

Normally at this point I would say that graphics don't really matter, and it is gameplay, story and replayability that’s important. I would dearly like to say that about this game, but I just can't quite say that. I did enjoy many things about this game, it is basically the same as Asylum and City but with some cool new moves put in which work from the FEAR suit. I do love the design in this game. The way Batman's suit looks is seriously cool, and Gotham City is beautifully detailed and huge in scope. The new thing in this one is the Batmobile, I know a lot of people hate it, but I actually rather enjoyed it, but it is certainly overused. I particularly don't like it when you are literally driving the batmobile inside buildings to solve environmental puzzles. I get it, you've got this cool new thing, and you want to show it off, but there is no need to try and force it in to nearly every part of the game.

I did like the story of this game, I particularly like the references to The Killing Joke, and how they brought back a certain character. Many of the moments in the story were very emotionally charged in a way that the previous games lacked. What is a shame is that the game lacks the great boss battles that the previous games were so memorable for. Scarecrow as the main villain I found particularly disappointing. I've always found him interesting as a psychological manipulative villain, but all the stuff about him in this game just basically comes to nothing. There's also another villain in this game whose story is a bit odd, without wanting to spoil anything all I can really say is that it's just kind of lame the way they try to hide something which is very obvious to any Batman fan. They could have just done his story a lot better, and it could have been amazing, but as it is, it's just kind of a messed up opportunity.

I cannot give this game a thumbs up and I do not recommend it. It is not completely unplayable to me, and as described the game has a lot of commendable things. If you are a fan of the series and have to play it, then yeah get it, but do be aware that for a lot of people it is still unplayable. If you can get it on another system or are able to wait then don't get it now on Steam. Don't expect this game to ever be properly fixed. Warner Bros./Rocksteady have been saying for months about all the stuff they are going to do to fix it, but still haven't done all the stuff they said they would. They seem more concerned about getting the DLC up. Their idea of compensation is almost laughable, not that I ever wanted free stuff from them, I wanted a working game. But the way they treat their customers is disrespectful, and ultimately that is why I have to give this game a thumbs down.

Edit: well the game now runs quite well for me, with some tweaking. If I lock the framerate to 30fps to get a pretty consistent stutter free experience that looks quite nice. It's not perfect though by any means and 30fps is far from ideal, but I can live with it for now. My thumbs down still stays though I'm afraid. It took too long for them to even put a graphics menu in with a fully featured set of options, and the attitude from Warner Bros just was not what I would call good customer service. Even with the game working alright for me, it's still a bit of a let down compared to the previous games in terms of story and gameplay. I can't help but wonder what I'd think of this game had it been released in the state it is at now. But I'll never know the answer to that unfortunately.

30FPS CAP in 2015? Unplayable frame dips? Bugged in-game settings? SLI/Crossfire disabled from the get go? Don't get me wrong, the game core mechanics; combat, story meshes together quite well when the earlier mentioned issues doesn't ♥♥♥♥ it all up.

I preordered this game with high hopes for Rocksteady and WB's past accomplishment with their Batman series games. Well guess i was wrong; never again will i buy games from them.

Should you buy this game? NOPE, fak WB, Rocksteady & Iron Galaxy. WB KNEW that this game was BROKEN MONTHS B4 RELEASE and still had the balls to release it in THIS BROKEN state. Show 'em who's boss by boycotting their game and by using the steam refund 20 times over.

reviewText:
You do not have the graphical capability to fully enjoy this game. Whatever you think, your graphics card is most likely not powerful enough to support this game. That's all there is to it.

Against all warnings from friends, I pre-ordered this game along with the season pass to play it on launch date, like I've done with all of the Arkham series games. This is the first time however that I decided to get the game on PC, the last times were always on PS3. But since this game is next generation, I could not justify buying a PS4 just to play it, I instead decided to use my PC, which, while a year old at this point, is still very powerful, I can play most new games with the highest settings (Mad Max and Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain work smooth as butter with maxed out settings). This was not the case with Batman Arkham Knight on June 26.

While I was one of the lucky ones to be able to play the game at all, throughout my playthrough I had only 2 crashes which came at two unrelated random points. But otherwise, I could play the game and I was willing to overlook most problems, chalking it off as it'll get patched in the coming weeks, I mean it's not uncommon. My nVidia GeForce Experience optimal settings recommended that I minimalise all settings, which to me was shocking, how needy could the game be? So I ignored it and wanted to experience how bad it can get. And oh man, it got bad. The framerate could not handle anything and would often drop down to 1.

Throughout my gameplay I eventually had a system going where whenever I was out as Batman, I would set my texture quality to medium, shadow quality to low and level of detail on high, but whenever I was in the Batmobile and there was any kind of action, I had to drop the texture quality and level of detail back to low and back again whenever there were any kinds of cutscenes going on so I could enjoy the experience even slightly. But even then, I played the game and defended it, because in the end, when it all comes down to it, it's NOT a bad game.

I enjoyed the Batmobile sequences more the more I learned how to handle the controls and the innovations in combat when you're controlling Batman were definitely the best so far. The parts of Gotham you get the explore (and it's not the whole city, just 3 parts of it) are big, but not overwhelmingly so, because the Batmobile makes pretty fast to traverse around. The usual controls were a bit changed however which did confuse me throughout the game, but it's nothing too damaging to the overall experience. I had fun, enjoyed the story which I will not spoil, but I'm pretty sure everyone knows at this point, and managed to complete my normal playthrough to 100%. I decided to leave the New Game+ mode for whenever the game gets patched and I can play it with optimum settings.

So if I liked the game, why the negative review? Simple. This port is atrocious compared to the console ports. The PC port was a simple afterthought and was handled by another developer, not Rocksteady. So when push came to shove in releasing the game, all the innovations that Rocksteady made, were not translated properly and the game sufferred. As most of you know, it was so bad that WB had to take the game off Steam so that they could develop a patch. For 3 months. It is now October and the patch was released. Can people play this game now? Yes. Did they fix some major issues? According to them, they have. Have they really? No, the game still functions the same as it did before for me. I can still only play the game with minimum settings.

Honestly, I think the only way they could have fixed it would have been if they reworked the graphics engine for the game and I seriously doubt they want to do that at this point. WB PR solution to this is to give out all the previous Arkham games out for free to the buyers who've waited for 3 months and not returned the game back in the first week. I already have all the Arkham games. I think most fans do. They're the ones that made us want to buy this sequel. Plus, the games have been on every other sale for around 5 euros each, so I'm pretty sure everyone has them. I personally am not getting anything out of being patient and supportive from all this time. From my perspective, they've done nothing to improve my experience.

So no, don't buy this game. Not on PC. Wait a couple of years. Let it drop in price, naturally upgrade your computer with time, let them patch it over and over and only then you'll have a good enough reason to play it.
Or go play it on the consoles now, it works perfectly fine there.

reviewText:
PRE-RELEASE REVIEW

In its current state, it's a technical mess. A 30FPS lock, inconsistent framerates and the game deleting itself is the best TL;DR I can come up with. Disabling SLI improved the performance slightly, but the frames are still all over the place with the 30FPS lock taken off in the .ini files. It's an eyesore playing in the Batmobile and when gliding so have fun with any kind of movement around the city.

The actual game seems great, I managed to rack up a decent amount of hours despite the technical issues causing me to grit my teeth at times. Interesting story, further depth added to the combat system and just more of the same is what I wanted from the Arkham formula. It's a shame this is brought down by Iron Galaxy's ineptitude.

Thank you Rocksteady, Iron Galaxy, WB for the worst PC port in recent memory.

POST-RELEASE REVIEW

Performance is still below what I'd expect, but at least WB can sell their DLC now so that's alright. Maybe we need another pre-release" period for the game?"

reviewText:
So, they relaunched the game. As for those of us who waited patiently, we got nothing in return. However, if you're reading this review, you likely don't own the game yet, so this shouldn't influence your decision.

There is no SLI support. The game was patched to run better, but it is still far from fixed and not well optimised by any stretch of the imagination (they recommended 12GB of RAM if you're on Windows 10...). SLI support is still apparently coming, but perhaps Star Citizen will release before that happens.

I don't recommend this game. It's fine as a game, the combat has far too much of the batmobile (which really isn't engaging or exciting). It hasn't really advanced from Arkham City all that much.

Really, unless you're absolutely desperate for the game, you've waited this long, waiting longer for a sizeable discount would be advised.

reviewText:
When Batman Arkham Knight first came out on PC it was a complete disaster; I like many other PC gamers was very annoyed at how poorly it ran and how frequently it crashed; however I was on the lucky side of the stick and was able to complete the game.

On October 28th the Interim Patch was finally released (as well as all the DLC up until that point); the game also went back on sale and things from here started to look up - the game ran much better and there were a lot more options available for PC users such as framerate cap, Anisotropic Filtering, higher quality textures, shadows and lighting. Since Oct 28th the game received an update every month (up until the point I'm writing this review) that would have performance fixes, stability improvements and included DLC that was being released monthly in the Season Pass.

Batman Arkham Knight runs a lot better than it did on day one; provided you meet the system requirements you should have no issues running the game. Just make sure you have the latest drivers.

I haven't focused much on the gameplay/story side because there are thousands of other reviews out there - I will say this; if you're going to get this game you need the Season Pass; the extra DLC, AR challenges, Story Packs and Skins really adds necessary depth to the game.

I am quite happy changing this review from a negative to a positive - I would also imagine most negative reviews are pre Oct 28th. I'm not endorsing the state the game was originally released in but the fact is it runs a lot smoother; if you are still holding off buying the game just go and get it.

While it may not be the epic finale we deserved it's still a great game any 'Arkham' fan should pick-up.

P.S. I can guarantee people will rate this down because even 7 months later it's still the cool thing to hate on this game.

reviewText:
Now I could make this whole review just centered around how this whole pc port of B:AK is completely broken and that you should avoid this game at all cost until it's fixed. But there are already over thousands of reviews about that so you don't need me telling you the game is for most people unplayable. Bad Frame Rate, Game Crashes, Horrible Textures, etc...But I'm gonna center this review around the actual story and gameplay.

Batman: Arkham Knight takes place one year after Arkham City. Ever since (spoiler to city) The Jokers Death crime has decreased to a all time low. All That changes when one fearful night Scarecrow announces that he will detonate a chemical weapon of his fear gas in the city, causing most citizens to evacuate. Leaving the City full of thugs, Batman Villians, and The GCPD (or whats left of it). It's up to Batman to find scarecrow and save Gotham from this Chemical Attack. But Scarecrow is Not Alone. He has Assembled, The Penguin, Two-Face, The Riddler, Harley Quinn, and A new Villian leading A private Militia Army Calling Himself The Arkham Knight" (Who's main motivation throughout the whole game is the Death of The Batman) to help him take down the Bat. The story had me hooked from the beginning. There were quite a few moments where I just sat there with my mouth opening so suprised at what's happening/happend.

Some of the Side missions aren't as interesting as they were in Arkham City but there still fun and interesting to do nonetheless. Introducing new characters
date: interesting side stories. And Seriously....Fudge the Riddler and his trophies. Can't wait to beat his ♥♥♥ when I actually get around to finding them.\n\nThe gameplay is as solid as ever. Batman is at his prime in this game with more moves
recommended: more and improved strategies on how to take on goons
hoursPlayed: alot more fighting animations for the caped crusader along with many new enemy types that will have you planning who to take out first. The game also for the first time introduces
voteText: something great
helpfulPercent: The Ability to drive the Batmobile through Gotham and taking out goons and unmaned tanks that the Arkham Knights militia will use to try and take you out. While I love the batmobile I felt like the game has too many situations where you have to rely on it to help if your stuck in a area or stumped on a riddler challenge. Even in story it tries way to hard to shove the fact that you can drive the batmobile in your face. So just know you may get tired of it at times
votesHelpful: atleast for story and side missions and such. The thing I was looking forward to the most though in this game was the ability to reach great heights overlooking Gotham City while gliding. Gliding through gotham wether right above streets watching goons or gliding past the tallest buildings in the game. It feels so satisfactory. You truly feel like your The Batman.\n\nIt's a great story and really fun gameplay. Hopefully when they get the bloody thing to work properly people will be able to enjoy just how great a game this is. Probably the second worst thing about this game though behind the horrible pc port...is the constant fact that they constantly shove in your face that they made Origins cannon with RockSteadys Arkham Games. I was not a fan of Origins and too this day I say the game never happened. Sure it be a ok game if it wasn't suppose to be tied to The Arkham Series but it is and I cringe whenever they make a remark in Arkham Knight of something or someone that was in Arkham Origins. And it's hard to forget it when you see old villians from Origins in it
votesTotal: or when characters talk about something that happened in it. *Sigh
votesFunny: All in all its a great game but I will keep the thumbs down reccomendation until The PC Port is fixed.\n\nUPDATE: 4 Months now and even after the patch
commentsCount: it's still broken

reviewText:
Intel i7 4790k @4.0Ghz
2x EVGA Superclocked GTX 970 4GB
Corsair Vengeance 1866mhz 2x4GB
256GB Crucial mx100 SSD

*******************
UPDATE
*******************

I have achieved stability.
60 fps with the extremely rare drop to around 45.


1. Edited the ini file and edited the framelock

2. Edited the NVIDIA game profile of batman via NVIDIA Control Panel - Manage 3d Settings - Program Settings - Batman: Arkham Knight;

SLi Rendering mode = Single GPU
Vertical Sync = Off

3. Changed Batman Graphic Options.

Display mode = Fullscreen
Resolution = 2560 x 1440
V-Sync = Off
Antialiasing = Off
Texture Resolution = Normal
Shadow Quality = High
Level Of Detail = High
Interactive Smoke/Fog = Off
Interactive Paper Debris = On
Enhanced Rain = On
Enhanced Light Shafts = On

******************************************************************************************
Original Issue

First off SLi doesn't work - That's to say it does use my second GPU, however, performance is WORSE than just using a single GPU. Secondly the benchmark tells me with 1 GPU running I get a miminum of 56 fps and a max of 93 fps...Actual game tests report I get a max of 60 FPS since I edited the ini file, BUT I'm getting drops to 19fps. Add this to the micro stuttering and the fact I have all the settings on low and I think you'll see this game needs a few patches to save it.

Back to The Witcher 3 for now.

reviewText:
Batman Arkham Knight is one of 2015's biggest releases.


If you're on Console.
WB Games has released another technological wonder; Arkham Knight! It's a wonder in a sense of ''how the hell did this get past play testing'', kinda similar to their last wonder of Mortal Kombat X.

Over the past few months while Rocksteady was patching this game, I defended them, I said it worked fine for me, hell, I was happy with that September patch.

This patch? It's more of a bittersweet situation. On one hand of the situation; we got all the DLC, which is a great thing for Season Pass holders like myself, if only I had gotten the content when it released like the Season Pass advertised.

Then the compensation? YOU; THE PLAYER GET THE LOVELY PRIZE OF.... All the Arkham Games, cause you know, anyone that has this is, the final installment in the series, definitely wouldn't have the first 2 (or three if you count Origins) and a 2D sidescroller that they ported from the 3DS. Pretty much nothing in my opinion.

If you're gonna offer compensation, offer it right.

Also, the game is still bugging out even more after that patch.

reviewText:
I'm so glad they finally fixed this. Now I can pay to get all the DLC of the console version while it still runs like garbage on my computer despite meeting the minimum specs and cranking every setting through the floor. I'm not saying I expect every game in a franchise, especially one spanning multiple years, to have the same requirements, but on minimum it looks like garbage compared to the previous Arkham games... and somehow runs worse. I would almost be impressed if I hadn't wasted money on this. On the bright side, the latest patch improved performance from sub 15 frames per second average to sub 17 frames per second average, an improvement of not nearly enough %.

UPDATE:
As of November, the game is still shamefully broken, but at least there's more DLC support. In solidarity with idiots who purchased before knowing how broken the game is, the minimum specifications still reflect some fantasy port we didn't get so anyone who browses the store page will not know that apparently they need 12GB of RAM to get the game to run on Windows 10, because how to program. But at least the November DLC is supported with the new patches.

reviewText:
WOW, MIGHT BE THE WORST PC PORT THIS YEAR.

MY PC SPECS

I7 4790k
Msi gtx970 (2)
16gb of ram
corsair ax860 power supply
crucial m500 960gb ssd

First off they don't let you change the frame rate past 30 in game, in my opinion because they new no machine could run this game in any setting over that because of such HORRIBLE OPTIMIZATION!!!!!!!!!!

Then they make an sli profile that I personally see worse results then with one gtx 970.
I would have prefered if they made this game well optimized and not have a day one horrible sli profile

I tried runnig the game on LOW SETTINGS with ALL NVIDIA GAMEWORKS FEATURES OFF and still dip under 30 fps on the regular.

THERE SHOULD BE NO GAME THAT REQUIRES A GAMING RIG THIS POWERFULL TO RUN BELOW 60FPS ON 1080P ON HIGH SETTINGS LET ALONE ON LOW

LONG STORY SHORT - if you like playing games in 1080p at 60fps THIS IS NOT THE GAME FOR YOU!!!

luckily for anyone who bought this game you can get refunds now. I got it free when I bought my second gtx970 and I'm still upset about this, so I can only imagine how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ I would be if I pre ordered this game (which I don't  pre-order games anymore, ever since assasins creed 3)

Hopefully the community can come up in arms and force the developer to fix this joke of a port by requesting a refund in mass numbers.


I came into this franchise back when Arkham city came out, My first preorder (for ps3) which I loved at the time, then played arkham Origins which ran decently, but had game breaking parts early on (luckily it was patched and works pretty good now) Best case scenerio the developer show's that they actually CARE ABOUT THE PC PORT and will make a patch as soon as possible.

If you haven't bought this game yet consider yourself lucky and wait until a patch comes out to make this game playable at respectable frame rates.


EDITED:

I still can't 100% or even 50% recomend this game, unless you have a 980ti and up, or a g sync monitor, but since the last review
I changed the max fps from 144 to 60

turned off sli profile

and I'm now able to run the game around 45 to 60 fps for 80% of the time with the occasional dips to 30 Which doesn't sound great, but IF YOU HAVE A G SYNC MONITOR, and don't mind playing it in mostly low settings, the gameplay is refreshed enough with a story so far that is my favorite of all the last arkham games gameplay wise"
date: I personally do like the car mode and tank mode addition.\n\nPLEASE MAKE THIS GAME RUN BETTER DEV'S hopefully they patch this wtihin the week so people can enjoy this game on pc"

reviewText:
Underneath the issues and poor performance is a game I'd really like to enjoy. Underneath all the bugs, is a game I'd love to experience at its best. Underneath the missing graphical effects is a game I'd love to see in it's true form.

But that is not Arkham Knight PC version. Arkham Knight on PC is one of the worst ports I have ever come across. I honestly did not think a game could be as horrible as AC Unity. But I am proven wrong.

The game's mechanics seem very nice so far even though I am very early into the game and it's story. But the constant FPS drops and overall stuttering is a HUGE turn off to play this game to begin with. The lack of graphical settings to choose from is pathetic. The fact that the game is locked to 30 FPS and can only be disabled by editing an ini file is rediculous. I have seen many people trying to help each other out by giving out tips on editing the ini file to increase performance. Which is nice to see I'll say that. It's not often I see the gaming community trying to help each other out.

But a AAA title should NOT and I repeat NOT be released like this to the consumers. It is utterly disgusting that players themselves have to actually take time to edit ini files to try squeeze out as much performance as they can even though they meet the recommended requirements or are even far above them. I've seen some people call others entitled" and to "relax it's just a game" as well as "if you don't like it
date: get a refund" among other more nasty comments. Thats entirely besides the point and honestly
recommended: the people dishing out those comments need to wake up and realize that releases like this are just a big no. You wouldn't want to buy a physical product and have it barely work would you? "Oh it's just a TV
hoursPlayed:
it's ok that it stutters and that the screen goes black every 5 seconds" I doubt you people would be fine with that would you?

The point is that a AAA publisher and developer should not be releasing something like this to their consumers. Paying $60/+ for something that runs like pure garbage is just unacceptable. And WB deserves every bit of hate they get for it.
They knew very well what the PC version was like. And they still released it.

The story so far to me seems to be interesting enough. But I still feel like it's going to be difficult to enjoy it due to all of the issues present in the game. This game could have been an amazing PC release. But due to WB's lack of care and poor choices on the PC Port. I honestly cannot recommend this game to anybody. Unless it's bugs and performance issues are resolved

reviewText:
Let me start by saying that I'm a huge fan of Arkham Asylum and City. They're among my favorite games (City being my all time favorite). So naturally I was very excited for this game. I had full faith in Rocksteady after their previous works but unfortunately, they ♥♥♥♥ed up. Arkham Knight is one of the most disappointing games I've ever played. You probably already know how horrible the port is, so I'm not going to talk about that. I'll focus on the game itself.

Let's start with the story. I personally didn't like it. I found it cliche and boring. There is not a single memorable moment in the entire campaign. It is unbelievably cliche. Same with villains. Scarecrow was awesome in Asylum. Here, he is a joke. He doesn't do anything, just talks about fear. Arkham Knight is even worse. He is very boring and weak. He calls you a coward but hides behind an army of drones. His 'boss battles' are terrible. His identity is ridiculously obvious. If you have the slightest comic book knowledge you'll immediately know who he is and if not don't worry, game tells you who he is way before it is actually revealed. Also SPOILER ALERT I'm really sick of these people's obsession with Joker. I get it he's a good villain but he doesn't need to be the main villain in all Batman games. Oh yeah, you thought this was about Arkham Knight? Nope! Joker is the main villain again. ♥♥♥♥ you Rocksteady.

Gameplay is also kinda messed up. Many people claim it's the best in the series but it's not. It has a few nice improvements and it has much more depth but it lacks the smoothness that made Asylum and City so great. Input drops, attacking an armored enemy instead of the normal enemy right next to him, losing combo for no reason are only some of these problems. The new environmental takedowns look cool but they are unreliable. Sometimes they cause you to drop your combo for no reason. Same with picking weapons from ground. The detection on these thing was so bad, I stopped using them after a while. Also the camera during combat felt a little more zoomed in than previous games and it often caused me to lose my combo. I also hated the new big enemies. They're essentially the armored enemies from City but they're so hard to distinguish in the heat of combat. In City, they wore red vests so you'd immediately spot them. Here, they look like regular enemies but just bigger. Fear takedown is also a new addition, it looks cool but its implementation is awful. Forget about relying on that thing. Anytime I wanted to use a fear takedown in a tight spot Batman just punched air and got me killed.

Of course the big new thing in this game is the batmobile. It's fun for a bit but it's way overused. You use it to get around, solve puzzles, fight tanks. Game forces it on you so much. You can't take two steps without it and I'm sorry but that's just stupid. Just like Riddler race tracks. I mean, just think about it. Riddler creating race tracks for batmobile. Nice one Rocksteady.

Arkham City had great side missions. Admittedly, they were a little repetitive. What I mean is, they mostly consisted of doing the same thing 3-4 times. Arkham Knight takes this to a ridiculous level. Almost every side mission in the game has you doing the same thing time after time again. Specially those god damn Militia missions. They're just a cheap way to increase the game's length in my opinion.

Remember challenge maps? They're gone. They are replaced with AR challenges and these suck. You cannot play as other characters in them and they have awful blue walls around them. So disappointing. There is only one fun AR challenge and you don't even play as Batman in that one. More than half of these damn things are for batmobile. We get it Rocksteady. You're really proud of that damn tank. Stop shoving it to our faces.

If you've made it this far you probably noticed I suck at long reviews and I agree with you. So I'll stop here. Batman Arkham Knight is a terrible port, it has a boring, cliche story, good but not good enough combat, way too much batmobile, the worst villains of the series, awful side missions (a couple exceptions) and a very disappointing ending. Way to end your legacy Rocksteady.

reviewText:
I trusted you Rocksteady... and you betrayed me. Never again.

Pros
- Some of the interior environments look nice
- More open world than Arkham City, though it looks ♥♥♥♥♥ier. (Thanks consoles)

Cons
- Poor performance (Framedrops, optimization)
- Looks bad in some areas (I have the game pretty much maxed out, other than the greyed out options)
- Story is poorly done so far (I.E. Only a few minutes in as Batman, and they immediately give you the batmobile... rather than tease it, and it being more satisfying later on)
- Crashes
- No external graphics options like the other 2 Batman games (Seriously. What. The. ♥♥♥♥.)
--- The graphics options are ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥ (Not nearly as good as the previous games)
- This feels like a ♥♥♥♥ing Xbone port, as well as feeling ♥♥♥♥ing rushed.

Holy ♥♥♥♥ am I dissapointed. I spent an hour staying up and decrypting files to find out this ♥♥♥♥ was gimped on the ♥♥♥♥ing PC, which is ♥♥♥♥ing funny because the two other games were ♥♥♥♥ing amazing on PC. I feel so ♥♥♥♥ing betrayed. Rather than giving us the experience we recieved with the previous 2 games, which was amazing, you give us this pile of broken garbage that has no ♥♥♥♥ing consideration for the PC populace. I won't be playing this untill it's fixed, which will probably be after WB Games counts all the money it just jewed from everyone.

Yep, It's a ♥♥♥♥ing console port: http://www.kitguru.net/gaming/development/matthew-wilson/arkham-knight-pc-port-was-outsourced-to-a-console-studio/


----- OCT.29 EDIT -----

I don't see too big of a change here other than more graphics options. Game still runs wonky, even after 4 months.

Here's the story of Batman AK: it released as one of the worst PC ports of all time, if not THE worst one. WB tried to scam PC users by giving us a poorly ported, buggy, unplayable mess and the whole thing blew up in their faces.

So what did they do? They removed the game from sale, of course, and promised they wouldn't put it back on sale until they managed to fix all the issues it had. It took them four months to do this.

So, what changed during those four months? Here's a list:

reviewText:
Please read this review before you buy the game!

Batman: Arkham Knight is a great game! But the game is really bad optimized, i mean really. When i started to play the game i found out it's capped to 30 fps, but you can change it in the game files. but the problem is that when you drive around in the Batmobile you get around 10-15 FPS! And that is really BAD, because you don't want to play a game where you only have 10-15 FPS, you can't play a game with 10-15 FPS! So before you buy this game be ready for FPS lag, i would say you should wait for patching!

But because Batman Arkham Knight has such a great story i would give it a 7/10. If the game was optimized it would give it 9/10!

P.S. There is A LOT of spike lags in the game!
