reviewText:
Mandatory complaint about one of the game's many issues:

Personally I did not experience any kind of crashes so I consider myself lucky in this department, I have seen and read of other's experiences with this. The only thing I experienced throughout the game was the drop in frame rates especially in instances where the batmobile showed up, cinematics, or entering a new zone. Hell even turning around really fast sometimes caused this. It's awful, it's bad, fix please.

PC specs:

i7 3770 @ 3.4
8 GB RAM
gtx 660
Win 8

Actual game review:

Despite all this I was able to complete the game to avoid the internet spoiling any major goodies this game had to offer. Overall I was pretty happy with the game. The story was great. The batmobile was really fun to drive and unlike many games that allow you to drive a vehicle the batmobile is unstopabble, you're not gonna get stopped by a bench, or a tree, or even a pillar. Boss fights is where I felt this game kind of dropped the ball, I know Arkham Origins is usually ridiculed by the fan base but they handled boss fights quite well, in fact all of the arkham series games did, but Arkham Knight kind of dropped the ball here. Your boss fights will consist more of fighting mobs or you in the batmobile. I definitely enjoyed the side missions this time around and the riddler's race tracks.

reviewText:
This is why you don't preorder games.  Not going to go into technical issues here; they're well documented.  This is the worst PC game I've purchased since Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition.  GreenManGaming unfortunately doesn't offer refunds, and if there's any consolation it's that I only paid $34 for something that isn't worth 34 cents.  I hope there are people out there willing to speak with their wallets, something I've screwed up royally at this point.  It's clear that Warner Bros. Interactive doesn't give a rat's ♥♥♥ about its PC players.  Let's show them how fed up we are with being ♥♥♥♥♥♥ on at every opportunity they can muster.

I wish I was able to do my job as poorly as the developers and publisher of this game and still be paid for it.  What a wonderful industry, and if I have learned any lesson from this it's that I should either stop throwing my money at anything before it's widely available or to buy from Steam to take advantage of the new refund feature.  Hopefully GMG jumps on that bandwagon sooner than later.

Give 'em hell, boys and girls.

reviewText:
Steer clear, for now anyway.

The game is riddled with performance issues on launch, 6/22. The game suffers from massive stuttering which appears to be caused by the game world streaming in the background. The game world seems to pop-in right before your eyes. Plenty of games are able to achieve smooth gameplay whilst also being open world. This is not acceptable, Rocksteady.

Additionally, Rocksteady seems to think covering the game in blur filters, aggressive depth of field and what appears to be chromatic abberation looks good. It does not look good, and you cannot turn off these options within the game. The image quality is very disappointing. Instead of Gotham being beautiful, it looks like a washed-out blurry mess.

I am considering a refund.

reviewText:
To be perfectly clear, I love this game, I think it is a fantastic game and it is one of my new favorite games, but you can't deny the fact that this game is a ♥♥♥♥ poor PC port.


This game represents everything wrong with PC development. Let me make a list of everything wrong with this game.

-Locked 30 FPS
-Lack of graphical options
-Horrible performance and frame drops
-Graphic glitches (texture bugs/artifacts)
-Constant crashes
-Small, inexperienced team ported the game (12 people developed this PC port)

So the game is locked at 30 FPS, and can easily be unlocked in a config file, but is cleary locked considering at anything above 30 fps you get constant FPS drops and it becomes an unplayable stuttery mess. I have a mid-range system too, nothing too high-end, but I should be able to mange 60 FPS at the lowest settings at 720p (Core i5 4690k, R9 270, 8gb Ram) but nope, at 720p low settings, I do sometimes get 60 FPS, but if I even move I drop to 40-30 FPS, and it becomes hard to do, anything really. It is VERY noticable while driving too, and it just becomes a headache. There are also only 3 standard graphic options (leaving out gameworks ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t), texture quality, which only has 2 settings, low and normal, shadow quality, which is low-high, and Level of Detail, which is also low to high. This is unacceptable and needs to be fixed. This game shows EVERYTHING that is wrong with modern PC ports and this needs to change.

As stated before, this is one of my new favorite games, but when it comes down to it, this is just an unacceptable port.

*Edit: Will update after a patch is released for a more proper" review of the game."

reviewText: All the PC release issues aside... A huge dissappointment. The plot elements are clumsy and heavy handed. But the worst of it all is the Batmobile. This is NOT a Batman game. Replacing bossfights with repetative Batmobile segments is unforgivable.\n\nIt reminds me of the Simpsons episode where they added Poochie to the Itchy and Scratchy -show. After a dismal initial reaction, Homer insists they keep the character, and that Poochie should be angier, louder and have access to a time machine. And when Poochie isn't on screen, all other characters should be looking around asking Where's Poochie?". It feels like that was the thought process when developing the Batmobile for this game. Sucks."

reviewText: Batman: Arkham Sh*te

reviewText:
CPU: i7 2700K @ 4.5 (OC)
GPU: MSI GTX 980
RAM: 32 GB
G-SYNC Monitor (144Hz)

I only include the above to give context to what I am about to say about the performance of the game...

MIN FPS = 32
MAX FPS = 60

GRAPHICS = High
All NVIDIA features were disabled (I tried with them all ON and the fluxuations became worse)

I unlocked the FPS from 30 and my experience was that during gameplay it would fluxuate between the MIN and MAX FPS  during combat (More so with the Batmobile involved).  While moving about the city it would hold steady at 60 FPS until enemy AI would engage Batman.

Overall I find the graphics appealing, and in terms of combat it is what you would expect out of a Batman game and holds up to the previous titles in the series.  I like what little I have played but I MAY hold off on playing it in the hopes of a patch that resolves some of the current performance issues.

I'm still glad I picked it up, however that being said I realize I have a fairly beefy system not everyone has the luxury of having and I am running the game better than most at the moment.  For that reason and that reason alone I must NOT recommend this game.  Simply put the developers got lazy with the port, IF and when these issues are resolved I will change my review to reflect said changes brought forth by the developers.

reviewText: Where do I even start? I ordered this with the promo for my gtx 970 and thought I would be getting the Harley Quinn DLC I was grossly mistaken. This is something that Rocksteady takes very seriously. We are working closely with our external PC development partner ." They did not even have the decency to por the game within their own studios. The final nail in the coffin is the fact that they neglected to tell pc users that they would be using Denuvo DRM. In the end sure I got a free game but maybe next time they should give their consumers full disclosure so when making 329 dollar decsions they will think twice and buy a different brand video card. I was excited that it came with two free games one of them being the witcher which has had no real issues and the other bineg this broken game. Well done my hat is off to you guys at rocksteady I was going to buy the 40 dollar season of dlc but now that money is going elsewhere."

reviewText:
With a system thats currently middle of the pack between the min req. specs and current top end for pcs in general, this is still nearly unplayable. Sub 1fps during the opening scenes, and during the the batmobile scenes. 10-15 the rest of the time. Turning all settings to the lowest/off, and with the resolution at 1280x720, it's still not very nifty and windowed mode made little difference.

And while yes, this is a BRAND NEW RELEASE... Dear god Rocksteady, your previous titles rocked our socks off, why the terribad performance this round?

This plays worse than gta4 did after release. At least that had consistant lag for me, so it was playable, if slowly. the fps spikes are too random for me to bother with just yet.

Waiting for an update.

patch #1 update; controls randomly freak out and get stuck in one directional path (constant a press to head left for instance.) no improvement ingame (though expected, still sucks.) and the game exit crash is gone, as well as it causing explorer to lock up. some good, some bad.

Most of the side missions require you to be fast and have split second timing. Sadly, with things the way they are, you can't even have multi second timing. I've gotten up and gotten a glass of water and come back to it just starting to unfreeze.

reviewText:
I tried to hate you... but this game is just beautiful :D
I think Rocksteady should be ashamed of themselves right now. They put a 30 fps cap on a 2015 tripple A game? Companies that make these kind of decisions are a cancer to the PC gaming comunity. They could have done a better job on optimizing and I am incredibly disappointed.

But on the plus side, once you remove the frame cap it plays like any other game except I was wondering how the combat system changed from the gameplay trailer?

So overall I cannot recomend this game due to the poor optimization, the 30 fps cap and the missing features. Once all of this is fixed I will update my recomendation.

Update #1:
6/30/2015
So 10 hours into the game I have noticed 1 bug where a tank was stuck in the floor and I have noticed 1 fps drop... Then again I am running this game on a 980 ti and on an ssd, but I can't imagine every gamer being fortunate enough to afford such a crazy setup. I still can't recommend this game just because Rocksteady really blew it. We still don't have a date for the fix which is horrible.

One way for Rocksteady to fix this would be to add special features to the PC version like maybe Ultra (8k?) textures, additional free content, maybe make the season pass free or why not just all of those thing? The launch of this game was a huge disappointment to the PC gaming community and even though I enjoy every second of this game I honestly can't recommend it until we get a proper functioning game with an apology and some kind of compensation.

Update #2:
7/7/2015
After 18 hours finally defeated the main story arc and a couple side quests. I have had exactly 3 crashes which were higly annoying but not so tragic for 18 hours of gameplay. Experienced 1 texture pop. Other than that I can't really complain a lot, I mean sure they should have optimized te game a lot better but it worked for me. Rocksteady made an amazing game, everything from the visuals to the story are amazing and I can't wait to recommend this game to everybody as soon as they fix it. Thank you Rocksteady for this amazing experience which was an amazing conclussion to the Arkham Knight trilogy.

reviewText:
There is no savior..no more hope..no more Batman.
In the final installment (hopefully) of rocksteady's Arkham series you play as Batman (obviously) faced with the reality that the Joker is finally dead. We see Batman differently in this game, he's losing it, his mind, his power, his reality. When Scarecrow threatens Gotham with a new toxin, it leaves the city in the control of the criminals, the police barely struggling to keep order. Batman needs to even the odds.

I'll start off this review by telling you that I had no known issues with my copy of the game. I removed the FPS cap and it ran smoothly, except for one crash. While I can't be too upset on this front, I must admit that it does upset me that others weren't able to play this on day one. Regardless, this review is about the game, not the launch.


Pros:

Gameplay[/h1]

The combat is as smooth as expected from rocksteady. This carries over into the Batmobile. When you first get into the driver's seat and accustomed to the controls you'll be surprised at how well it works. Both modes. Passive and Aggressive. Each one has it's own set of moves, gadgets, abilities and more to choose from. You'll progress through the game getting more upgrades to help your sense of superiority.

Story[/h1]

Starting from months after the Joker has been creamated, You (Batman) begin to have maddening halluncinations wreck your brain as you go from area to area, creeping closer to the inevitable loss of your sanity. Backed by the reapperance of Scarecrow, You are pushed to his limit in this game. Or at least as much as he could be. You're a bit darker, a bit more crazy, a bit more insane. The story works, it does, from minor events to the more major, everything feels like something Batman would have to deal with.

Music[/h1]

Nick Arundel has done it again. The music has tones of the orgininal, mixed in with it's own idiviulaity feeling. You'll get a blend of a little bit of the old mixed with the new. The music doesn't outshine at any parts in the game. The soundtracks is Batman's own. It's hard not to easily fall in love with it.

Voice Acting[/h1]

Kevin Conroy, as per usual gives us an amazing and vibrantly dark Batman voice. Mark Hamill returns and haunts your character. In more than one way. The voice acting is done nice, while a couple lines did feel forced in the beginning, it seemed to work itself out by the end.

Artwork and Locations[/h1]

Gotham returns bigger and more impressive than Asylum and City. You can even see Arkham City in the back. The main three islands will keep you busy with flashy signs and dreary landscapes, skylines that were meant for Gotham are there. The whole city has this..gloomy feel that works well with the overall game.

Replay Value[/h1]

Getting in a total of 33+hours by completion, I can say that there is a New Game+ which if I wanted, I could go back and do it all again, and I just might. I'll be tracking down the rest of the riddles until then. But, still..it's a positive that there are the usual VR challenges that can keep you coming back, trying to beat yourself or your friend's scores.
[/list]

Cons:

Repetitive[/h1]

While progressing through the game, you'll receive missions. From stopping Two-Face from robbing Gotham dry or destroying Penguin's gun caches. You'll notice a pattern form.
<Introduce bad guy> ...
<Do bad guy missions> ...
<Complete and apprehend bad guy> ... While this is nice, they used this formula for almost every Top-Tier" robber/baddie. None of them felt intimating by the time I took them back to GCPD.

Bosses[/h1]

There are none. It's a tedious chore to take down the criminals. For example
date: Firefly.. you go from fire station to fire station
recommended: using the Batmobile's winch to extinguish the fires until the man who set them comes bursting out. You chase him in your ride until his fuel bar has been depleted
voteText: beating him down
helpfulPercent: he flies off. You do this three times before eventually removing his Jet pack. This..is not a boss battle. None of them were. There wasn't the satisfactory feeling of Killer Croc's fight
votesHelpful:
or Freeze's inventive battle. No moments where I was caught off guard or pleasantly surprised for good reason.
[/list]

Conclusion:Batman™: Arkham Knight is a game I wanted to love. That I wanted to recommend. I simply can't when there are two others
votesTotal: maybe even three other Batman games (asylum
votesFunny: city and maybe even origins) that I could recommend for more bang for your buck. I can recommend playing this game
commentsCount: I just can't recommend getting it at the current price tag for a couple reasons. Save your money for a sale
column16: wait for GOTY edition. This is a good wrap up to the Arkham series
column17: just not as great and explosive as you think it will be. Go into this game with a lot of skepticism."

reviewText:
This review will be changed when Warner Bros re-releases the game and fixes all the major issues. This is why the score is a Not Recommended.http://youtu.be/oQufkohUPwo
Game: Batman: Arkham Knight
Genre: Action-Adventure Open World
Developer: Rocksteady Studios
Publisher: Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment
Copy supplied by Nvidia

Batman: Arkham Knight is the final instalment in the open world action-adventure superhero franchise that started in 2009, and is developed by Rocksteady Studios and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment.

STORYNine months after the events of Arkham City, the Scarecrow developes an improved and deadlier version of his fear toxin and threatens to release it in the city of Gotham. The police evacuates all the civilians and stays behind to arrest all the criminals that are destroying the city and to help Batman capture Scarecrow and the other supervillains (Two Face, Penguin, Riddler, etc.). Also, there is a new enemy in town: the Arkham Knight, someone who built an army and invaded Gotham with the sole objective to kill the Batman.
Does this sound interesting? Yes, it does. Is it entertaining? Not really. While it starts strong, the story gets boring really fast: they try to make you care about multiple characters from the comics that barely made cameos in the previous games, the villains do almost nothing at all, the Arkham Knight's reveal is a huge disappointment and the 100% completion ending doesn't make much sense. Fortunately, the saving grace is the presence of an old character that comes back during the game, elevating the quality of the story quite a lot for me.

GRAPHICSThe game looks spectacular: huge city full of details and easter eggs, constant rain, beautiful animations and varied environments make this one of the prettiest games ever. However, as we all know the PC version also features missing features and painful optimization: even though I modified the .ini files and used a tweak tool, there are still many problems with the performance. And this is without talking about all the glitches that are present, like enemies disappearing inside walls, objectives that don't activate, entire riots of enemies that run away.
Note that this section will be updated once WB and Rocksteady fix everything, but we can't forgive them for this barely playable first release.

GAMEPLAYThe melee combat is mostly unchanged: you attack and counter enemies in brawl, while also adopting different attacks depending on which enemy you are fighting. Some nice improvements are the possibility to punch downed enemy without losing your combo, grabbing bats and other weapons to deal more damage and to use environmental kills. In some sections you are also helped by Robin, Catwoman or Nightwing, who are playable for a small amount of time each.
The open world is vast and features many tropes of recent Ubisoft games: control a tower, defeat strongholds, find collectibles. Fortunately, the varied environments, vibrant city and multiple side missions make this an enjoyable experience: gliding around the city, finding Azrael, looking for Riddler Trophies, saving firemens and helping the GCPD makes you really feel like you are the Batman.
And now, to the most diving section of the gameplay: the Batmobile. When I started playing, I loved it: it runs fast but you always feel fully in control, the combat controls are tight and precise and there are some interesting implementations in some puzzles. However, after 10 hours where you have spent over half of your time shooting tanks and chasing cars, it gets really annoying. The game becomes repetitive, and because of the Batmobile's presence, all of the boss fights have been changed with big tanks to blow up, and stealth sections have been reduced way too much.
While there are some nice additions, the side missions are very interesting and varied and the open world is fun to explore, the Batmobile is shoved down our throats and it becomes the most annoying element in the game, sucking most of the fun out of it.

CHALLENGEEven though I started on Hard, the game is very easy to beat: I found the fights shorter and easier to win, the stealth sections with many covers and AI that wanders alone, the Batmobile chases repetitive and the tank sections a dodge-and-shoot borefest.

SOUNDKevin Conroy, Troy Baker, Jonathan Banks, Grey Griffin and many other voice actors come back to the game, and they all work very well. The sound effects are great as always, as well as having the same powerful punching sound effects. The Batmobile also sounds fantastic, resembling the sounds featured in the Christopher Nolan trilogy. Nick Arundel also comes back as composer, and does a fantastic job enhancing your Batman experience.

REPLAYABILITYOpen world full of activities, New Game+ mode, 79 achievements, upcoming DLC and a ridiculous amount of Riddler challenges make this a game that us fans will keep playing for a long time.

Overall, I would recommend this game only when its technical issues have been fixed. Right now, the large amount of bugs, poor performance and missing graphical features don't make this a worthwile purchase. Also, the overuse of the Batmobile and uninteresting story will put off many players, making them miss the better paced previous installments. I wanted to love this game. I love all the others, and I went into this with high expectations. Unfortunately, I was disappointed.

Story: 7
Graphics: 5
Gameplay: 7.5
Challenge: 7
Sound: 8.5
Replayability: 8

ENJOYMENT: 7
FRUSTRATION: 8

reviewText:
I should start this by saying that I am a fan of the series.  I still think the Arkham games are a must play for anyone who likes games, console of P.C.  I even went as far as playing through this game even when it first released just because I have a huge appreciation for what the Arkham games brought the table when it comes to world building, art and game design.  With that said, the release of this game was a sham.  The game was unplayable for a huge chunk of the P.C. fanbase and even those of us who could play it had to deal with countless issues.  The season pass was shady, as usual, and months later we've come to find that the DLC that we got was just... disappointing- barely adding anything worth experiencing.

Bugs and DLC aside, the game itself is a bit of a disappointment.  The story feels flat and unsatisfying, Riddler is extra annoying with his unnecessarily large amount of trophies and really out of place Riddler races.  The Batmobile was a thing you were forced with deal with rather than a fun addition to the game.  The cast seems interesting and promising but fails to deliver; I really wanted to see more of Robin and Catwoman, Batman's interaction with his constantly-falling-appart family, anything.  It's the last game in the series, give the fans closure... but no.  Instead there's a repetitive and predictable story filled with the same tropes and structure anyone who's read a Batman comic in the past 10 years has seen over and over again.

With that said, the gameplay is still good ol' Arkham.  Combat is still fun and snappy, beating up thug after brainless thug is still satisfying.  The game is gorgeous when it wants to be and the art design is still awesome.  I guess that's a plus.  Let's face it, if you're a fan of the series you're probably going to get the game anyway but, as much as it pains me to say it, I would hold on to that thought.  Wait until it's in a better condition or even better, wait for a very deep discount.

reviewText: If my PC can handle the Witcher 3, I think it's fair to say this game should be no problem either. Sadly the performance is horrible, sometimes giving me less than 10fps (during the Batmobile sections). reviewText:
WAIT for updates to this game before buying.

While this isn't the worst PC port it does belong on a list of the worst.  It is a huge shame these days that big games like this are made for consoles and then ported, often by a completely different developer, to PC and a lot of them suffer for it.  This one sure does.

I am pretty confideant that they will eventually make it right, but we aren't there yet right now.

PC Port Problems:
* Capped at 30FPS unless you edit a file
* Textures are extremely low resolution, capped at MEDIUM in the settings and look very bad.  They look worse than on consoles.
* Many players even with high end rigs reporting performance issues with framerates all over the place

Myself with an I7-4770K and a GTX 980, with DEFAULT settings in the game, get a min FPS of 15 and an average FPS of just 18 when running the game's built-in benchmark.

reviewText:
===2nd UPDATE===
Here is a couple things that need to be mentioned first. 4 Months ago Batman Arkham Knight was pulled of Steam, at the time before the first miniature patch I was able to play this game fine at locked 30 fps and it was smooth due to community fixes. We all know who that is and he has done more work than entire Rocksteady and WB combined.

So 4 months have past and the interim patch broke my game much worse than the previous patch. So it was even more broken, once again I was forced to use community patches done by community and not WB and Rocksteady. Then today comes and I am expecting to play DLC's.

As you can see from my playtime I already pushed over 100Hrs into this game. Well guess what, I have troubleshooted multiple times and yet to recieve all said DLC supposed to be released today. I was expecting to be able to play DLC's but that is not the case. From what I read on Forums the Season Pass holders have some serious issues and have been pretty much scandaled.

Now Pros
-Game runs decent if you lower your settings and not overdo things. Gameworks look good.
-Story was very well done and even the Riddler challenges were decent.
-When game ran smoothly on launch for me game mechanics were amazing and fluid.
-Lots of funny references and well done comedy.
-Unexcepted Ending though depends what you think is good.

Cons
-Rain textures still buggy, Only work every once in while.
-Gamework options are horrible for performance and should not even be touched or turned on period
-Game runs worse then launch day.
-SLI is still not fixed for those with said setup
-Villian claimed to be original isn't at all but a lie. Die Hard Fans Know him very well
-WB support is horrendious
-Apparently game now needs 12GB of RAM on Win 10. This is not realistic at all.
-DLC Content not fully released to Season Pass Holders
-Compensation done by WB is worthless if a diehard fan. If you own the games then your out of luck.
-Promises still being broken and patch notes released are not even patch notes but a joke.

All said and done I would not recomment this game to anyone and if you have a console then get it for that instead. PC right now has been treated poorly and WB has done nothing but lie through their teeth. Many Claims made and promises broken. Releasing the game with no performance gains is unacceptable. Many have claimed performance has yet to change.

===New Information===
After almost 6 hours DLC content is now downloading and can't wait to play said DLC's. Though I hear that for some game is even more broken now with DLC's installed so I am crossing my fingers hoping I do not fall into that category. Though even with DLC's finally being released finally I still would not recommend buying this game for PC. Get it for Console since it works marvelously on that since the PC community was not a priority.

I will state though the story is fantastic and a masterpiece but sadly ruined by many of the game issues that plague this version. You can get the game running much better but you have to go really far out of your way to get the fixes and at least doable.

===Additional Update===
After playing the game after its re-release I will say the game still needs massive fixes.Without using 3rd party help from specific topics in Batman Arkham Knight forum this game would still be heavily unplayable for many.

Though WB recently announced that until the end of 2015 refunds through steam and only purchased through steam are available to get full refund without worry of your playtime. I have obtained my refund and is still pending but time will only tell if the game gets any more serious fixes. On top of that WB also mentioned that they will speak to the community about things that apparently can not be fixed in the game. Reason why I got my refund. This is a warning flag in my mind and so be wary of this title. Tried playing the DLC's but some like the Red Hood DLC kept crashing and I felt there was no story with that DLC. Just mostly you fighting a bunch of enemies and majority of the Vehicle skins can only be used in racing which is a shame.

reviewText:
I think it's important to contribute a review that doesn't just focus on the technical issues. I bought it recently and have played about 20 hours. I haven't had a single glitch in that time. Follow the recommended specs, and you should be fine.

For the game itself, it's both good and bad. I still like Asylum the best of the series. I think it was actually the right size in terms of gameplay with a good progression overall to both main and side quests. This game is enormous, and it's really not always in a good way.

First, the good:

The Batmobile is pretty awesome. I was genuinely surprised. I thought it would by clunky and pointless like most attempts to add vehicles into established series are, but it actually plays really well. I think the chase side missions involving the batmobile are some of the most fun in the game. The pseudo-destruction reaped upon the city as you mow down statues and cleave off corners of walls adds to the feeling that you're driving an incredibly powerful machine. Mowing down an entire riot of baddies sending them flying in all directions is also entertaining. It's over-powered, but the game compensates for that by locking off encounters that should be fought without it.

The new types of side missions are also cool. I like the addition of the flying drones, and the takedown method for them is clever. The different types of bad guys are managed well, and there are lots of creative opportunities for playing around with your abilities.

The Mediocre:

The story has its good points, but a lot of it is really melodramatic and predictable. Harley Quinn's voice is the single most annoying thing ever created. Picture everything she says as voiced by Jar Jar for added entertainment value. The way The Joker is handled is a lot of fun. I think that's the most entertaining part of the story. The part that's trying to be a Nolan movie just fell on its face for me. Yea, I get it already. Joker/Batman represent an ethical duality where they're both really two sides of the same coin. They exist outside the law pursuing their own view of the world at the expense of society based solely on their own beliefs. Blah blah blah. Please stop beating me over the head with it like it's not a simple, well-trodden idea. It works really well when they treat it as satire. The Joker has some great moments openly mocking you or egging you on. A number of times I wished I could actually choose to do what he suggested. That would've made a much better game in my opinion. There's also some good chatter of the generic bad guys commenting on elements of the world or just their own generic nature. When it tries to take itself seriously, it becomes dull in its trauma.

The Bad:

This game is huge. This seems like a weird thing to cite as bad, but it's so absurdly large that it becomes genuinely aggravating. The side quests are the biggest example. There's an entire wheel of side quests. I'm not sure how many there are exactly, but I'd estimate around 20. They're not just go somewhere, do the thing, and finish the quest type of deals. You go do the thing, and then five more of that thing appear an hour later. So you go do those five, but then still five more appear another hour later. After fifteen to twenty-five of them, you might finally be done. That's the case for nearly every single one of the twenty different side quests. Some things aren't even official side quests but still need to be eliminated anyway like the aerial drones.

So you clear out a sector of the map. Then you progress in the story a little, and all of a sudden that sector isn't clear anymore. It's not filled with something new and cool though. It just has a few more of exactly the same time-consuming thing you already cleared out the first time. It's fun clearing out the aerial drones the first 5-8 times. When they start appearing four more at a time in the late game, it's just painful. The checkpoints would also be fun just a few times, but there are like 40 of them to clear out. Many of the side quests are really just the same thing in a different situation." Rescuing firefighters
recommended: and clearing out watchtowers all involve taking out exactly the same clustered group of baddies in basically the same way. You're just doing it for a supposedly different goal. Every single one of those will have to be done so many times to fulfill their own quests that you'll have no desire to finish them. My hat is off to anyone who has 100% this game. That's a Sisyphean task to me.\n\nIt goes further. There are 243 riddler puzzles. I kid you not. I'm actually bored just by the idea of going after them all. It's obvious someone just went through the map after they finished this massive city and stuck a trophy in every single place you could possibly fit one. It's obnoxious. All of this goes against basic game design principles. Have a clear and varied progression that increases in challenge. Most of the content in this game is the same thing over and over. The unfortunate part of that is it really takes away from the parts of the game that are well-designed and do present a varied challenge. I understand they were trying to make a huge epic conclusion
hoursPlayed:
but they really cluttered it up and made it shallow by throwing in too much of the same kinds of content.

Synopsis:

Overall I recommend it. I paid about $13 for it on sale
voteText: and I think I got more than enough good content for my money. I'd pay up to $20 for it. Pay the price tag if you really love the series and know you can run it. The story isn't bad and does have both fun and cool moments. The batmobile is awesome to play with

votesFunny: and you'll have a good time with it. I'd say 7/10 for a rating."

reviewText:
What a astounding ♥♥♥♥ up this game has been. WB release broken game. Hideously broken. Unplayable for most users. They released it KNOWING this. Huge public outcry, so they pull game from shelves. They then sit virtually incommunicado for 4 months and release a patch that actually makes it WORSE fro some users. More silence. Two months later they put it back on sale after another patch, recommend that you have a MINIMUM 12 GB of RAM to run the game, release DLC they charge a fortune for despite it being uniformly crap, and offer as recompense free copies of the other Arkham games which 90% of purchasers already own.

I bought the season pass. I didn't get a refund, thinking (wrongly) that users would have the right thing done by them. I already own EVERY Arkham game, so for my patience and loyalty I get absolutely NOTHING. The behaviour of WB has been nothing short of disgusting. On these reasons alone I do not recommend you buy this or any other WB/Rocksteady game EVER. Play them if you like (and I'm sure you know how to arrange this) but do not give them your money. They simply do not deserve it.

As for the game itself...aside from the stuttering cutscenes, the way the dialogue that can't quite keep up with the graphics, and the frame drops (and I'm running a system with 32GB RAM and twin 4GB cards but dual cards areen't supported lol) and the tearing, and all the extra NVIDEA effects that cripple frame rate....it's ok. The timing on the combat seems out but you get used to it, the batmobile is cool enough but overused (oh and you can't use the DLC skins for it in game, only in the stupid races" which are just obstacle courses). The map is huge but a lot of it doesn't have much to do in it
date: aside from speeding past it in the batmobile. The story is ok
recommended: The gadgets are ok. The DLC is terrible - you can't even use all the costumes in game except in the AR challenges. Some of the new enemy types - medics
hoursPlayed: those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s with drones - are a nice addition.As for the mystery of the Arkham Knight? Took me 5 minutes to get it right. Ho hum.\n\nIs it anywhere as near as good as Asylum or City? No. If you want a good Batman game buy those. If you already own those get Shadow of Mordor (which is excellent just don't waste your time on the DLC) - the gameplay is essentially the same with a fantasy twist

reviewText:
Barring all the performance issues (of which there are many), this is a horribly mediocre way of ending what was once a fantastic series. Every twist can be seen coming by anyone who's even glanced at a piece of Batman lore, the new Batmobile mechanics are run into the ground by unimaginative and uninspired level design, and the hand to hand combat has never been simpler with the addition of several game-breaking gadget moves that utterly ruin any strategy the combat system had left after City.

If you need a level of comparison as to how sub-par this game is: It's like they set out to make a game more bloated and ham-fisted than Arkham Origins.

The sad thing is, they accomplished it.

reviewText: By far on of the worst PC ports I have ever had the displeasure of playing. I literally NEVER preorder games, but for Arkham Knight, I decided to, considering the series solid track record of PC ports. I own and have played all 3 previous games in the series, and they all ran beautifully on my set up (hd7970, intel i7). Enter Arkham Knight: A game with little to no graphics settings, a framerate that dips into single digits on the regular, and an awful DRM system. It's sad to see a series I have played and loved on the PC end like this. Do yourself a favor, do not purchase this game. From what I've read, the ps4 version runs at a near perfect 30 FPS, that's your next best bet if you wish to play this game at a reasopnable framerate.

reviewerDisplayName: 『 T I L T S T E R 』
reviewText:
First of all, there's a 30 FPS cap, that's bad... You can easily fix it with a quick googe search, so it's good now, right? Kinda... Not really...
The game is not well optimized, we need some stutter fix. When i just spin the camera i drop from everything between from 68 to 21 FPS. Super annoying when i'm gliding, as it can drop to even 1 FPS. I even used the performance test in the game and got solid 48+ FPS atleast, it looked smooth and quite sexy. Not what i get in the game though, it's not as sexy. :/

As long as it is like this, i do not want to recommend it. But atleast in the little sequence where i got into a fight, it was good, it felt like Batman combat, smooth 40 FPS, hehe...

EDIT:
Other than that let's review the rest of the game.
As of now i've gotten a bit more play time, so i'll break down somme of the elements in the game.

Combat:
I love it. The basic combat is easy and satisfying, it looks smooth and cool and you just land a sick punch after another. There are some more advanced combat, where you can sneak upon enemies and take them down easily in a chain from 3 to 5, a mechanic that makes it easier to take down armed enemies and it's a reward for stelathing.

The Batmobile:
It looks amazing, it's such a massive tool and has a beautiful design. The driving however, feels too heavy, it feels like you're driving a boosted tank, steering it is kinda weird, but powersliding works fine. There is however a combat mechanic in the batmobile where you kind of control it like a 4-legged sliding robot. This mechanic feels great, really. You can strafe with small boosters and steer through tight spaces easily and your winch to pull down stuff on the map is awesome.

Story so far: SPOILERS, maybe?
I'm still just in the beginning, but the main villain is Scarecrow(I love Scarecrow) and it's about his new chemical experiment(zombies, kind of?) and so far the interaction and cutscenes are pretty cool. I must say, it gets you in the story fast and keeps going like that as of now.

Graphics:
This game is beautiful. On High ofcourse. It does look good Low, but you can see the lack of details up close, especially on the batsuit. The rain/weather looks good enough to make a darker atmosphere.
But as it is poorly optimized i'm running my game on Low still. Could go High, but too many frame drops in movement.

Memory:
It's a really RAM heavy game.
I have 8Gb of RAM. While playing on Low and no AA. 3 Monitors, no programs other than Steam open. ~85% memory usage. Open Google Chrome, 95-100%. Just a heads up.

PS. Will edit as the game gets updates and I get further in the story.

reviewText: Rocksteady should be ashamed that they released the game in this state. Don't be fooled: the problems with this port are not subtle. They cannot be explained away simply by claiming that the issues are uncommon and weren't uncovered by play testing. I have a 980 ti, one of the most high end and expensive cards available for purchase. I had to turn down the settings to achieve a playable frame-rate. In one instant I'll be at 60-70+ fps, and a second later, I'll be at 25, with no difference in the action on-screen.\n\nOh, and don't forget, the only reason I was able to go over 30 is because I manually changed a config file that states any frame rate over 30 will make the game unstable. It blows my mind that a company would release a product in this state. It's all about greed. They are confident they can take your money, release an apology, and take their time fixing the most glaring issues in an economical way. Rocksteady deserves all the negative press they will continue to get, and more.

reviewText: Buy new graphics card( EVGA 980 ti SC). Install graphics card. Play games at max settings at 60 fps give or take a few. Nvidia is nice enough to give me a free game to test out my new card. Pre load game yesterday. Can't wait because I love this series.  Load the graphics settings. First thing I do is turn v-sync off. Then look at how little settings there are to change. Turn everything up to max and run pc diagnostic test . Runs from 61 fps to 156 fps through testing. Play game. I notice my frames cannot go above 30. I make sure I turned v sync off. Yep, it was off. Contemplated in my head that they actually caped a PC game.... Hour goes by and game crashes. Reload game and storm knocks my power out...... Turn PC back on and run game. still 30 fps. go to reviews and sure enough it was locked. Damn consoles.  Edit file to uncap the fps. 0/10 would not want to do a work around again. U wot Rocksteady?\n\nPS: Game runs ok, not great. Fps can dip to 30 fps in some areas. The game has crased five times on me, all being during a riddilers challenge. I like the main story so far. The side quests seem meaningless for the most part.

reviewText:
So this game had a horrible launch. I think we all know that.
But it's gotten a lot of work since then.
It's not perfect - I've had a total of 4 crashes (all while gliding in the air, oddly), the Batmobile controls could use some fine-tuning, camera glitches and zooms weirdly when flying the Remote Batarang through vents, performance isn't great, and some of the Riddler challenges are frustrating as heck - but it's still worth buying.

Having just gotten 100% completion (First time I ever did that in an Arkham game), I can say that this is a worthy entry in the series.  Better than Arkham City for sure, probably better than the others as well. Gameplay is great, the graphics are absolutely gorgeous, the story and writing are as excellent as ever, and it's overall absolutely worth the price of admission. I finished it a few hours ago and I'm still grinning.

If you were scared off by the fiasco of the original launch, give it another try.

reviewText:
Half way through August and still no fix, don't support this behaviour.
I kept the game in faith that WB would put all resources into fixing this terrible terrible port, gave them more benefit of the doubt than they had earned but it seems they are content to take the nock and keep 3/4 of their resources firmly on producing more DLC.

And if that's not true and most of the stuido are on this project then that just speaks to how much of a terrible product they tried to offload on us in the first place.

But they know people will make excuses for them and we all have short memories. WB and Rocksteady (to a lesser extent granted) need to understand gaming culture is changing, they make A LOT of money from us and it's about time we started to band together as consumers and demand better quality from so called triple A products.

I have cancelled my preorder of Mad Max and I'd urge you all to do the same - because what incentive do they have to QA a game that's already slipped deadlines, that they're trying to rush to market if they already have your money and you're content to give them an extra 2 months development time after you've already paid?

Simply cannot support a publisher that treats the consumer base with such disregard.

I'd like to add that of my 13.8 hours on record I've only progressed as far as the second island, the rest of the time has been spent trying various fixes, hardware set up's and ini tweaks.
All to no avail as I still get frequent stutters, pauses and crashes.

In this time I've upgraded my Graphics card (which works immaculately in every other new game in my library) I've updated to windows 10 and I've added another 8gb or RAM to see if the issue was the rediculous memory leak.

Nothing. Can't even get a smooth experience at 30fps 1080p on a gtx980ti with a devils canyon I5 @ 4.7 and 16gb 2100 RAM on a samsung EVO SSD.

For reference I play the witcher 3 at 1440p with everything on max except hairworks AA (on high) and foliage distance (high) @ mostly 70+fps.

reviewText:
Breaks my heart to say, as I am a huge fan of the series, and Batman in general. I think the content and gameplay is good to great, but the port is just so terrible.

I bought the game and the season pass on good faith, I sucked it up and played through it at 30fps, even though I upgraded to 2 980s solely for this game. I got the 100% ending, and decided to sit and wait on new game + and DLC until the performance was patched and the game reached its full potential.

Now it is rereleased offically, 2 or 3 big patches later, and not only is there still no SLI support, something that has been promised since the whole inital fiasco in June, but single 980 performance just can not maintain consistent 1080p 60fps without major visual concessions. I tried the first post release DLC side story with Batgirl, and it was a janky and jittry mess, even in small enclosed enviornments.

All of this with the recommended 16gigs of ram, and a system well above the recommended specs.

This is not the port we need, or deserve.

reviewText:
Bought it on release day, it ran like crap. Just picked it up in the sale and my god, it's like a whole new game. R9 290, i5-4690K, 8Gb mem, everything maxed except for shadows and it runs between about 45 to 60 FPS with very little stutter, or at least no more than I'm accustomed to from slapdash console ports. Which is to say, infrequent and bearable.

Is the game any good though? I don't know, only played about two hours so far. What I do know is..... the combat feels like it has far less weight to it than in the previous games; it feels more fluid, looks far more badass with all the leaping and froing, but it also feels easier somehow and as a result less engaging.

The batmobile isn't great. I mean, I play batman games to swoop around above city streets like a giant armoured lunatic, stalking my prey with my ominous cloak flapping meancingly in the wind. I don't play them to drive around, running people over while failing handbrake turns into buildings. If I wanted to do that I'd reinstall GTAV. So, the fact that the button that always used to be detective mode has now been mapped to GET IN THE bloomin' BATVAN on the 360 controller.... yes. This creates comedy. Plus, it drives like an excitable sponge.

Gotham looks gorgeous. I'm quite looking forward to finally giving it an explore.

Anyway, I'm going to give this a tentative thumbs up. Only because it's Batman, which is bound to be moneys worth, and it now works, and it's on sale. If the batbuggy bugs me out enough through the game I might reconsider, but right now, considering my play time, I see no reason to be churlish.

Update:

Okay, a couple of more hours in and I can happily say I'm having a blast. The batcart is not winding me up, in fact it feels quite well integrated into the game, the combat is just as much fun, and the story is beginning to suck me in. On this basis, that tentative thumbs up is a definate.

reviewText: I love the other games in the Arkham series, and played them with no issues. Frankly I play a ton of games both old and new, and rarely do I find a game to be just totally unplayable on any of my computers. It was a huge disappointment that this game had so many performance issues it was really unplayable to begin with, and even after their couple of patches it is barely playable with low fps in many areas and still some graphical artifacts.\n\nIf you do somehow manage to get the game running at a decent speed (which requires a better graphics card and more memory than any other game I have come across to even begin to play), then the game itself is okay but has seemed to me to be the weakest in the Arkham series since it ends up centered so much on requiring the batmobile. It is a lot of fun to have a new toy, but you are required to use it so much that it ends up feeling like a racing/tank shooter game half the time. The rest is pretty good and most of the things you liked about the previous games (if you haven't played them, you should) are still in there to some degree. I am sure it will be a great game in 5-10 years when it is patched either officially or unofficially the way it should be and when most people will actually have computers that will run it reliably.

reviewText:
LIVE REVIEW!

I'll be adding as I go on.  Let's get started:

HOUR 1

Game crashes on first launch, which is only fair as I seemed to be one of the few souls who got to play all 3 previous installments with zero technical issues.  Second time works, so I set about tweaking settings since my GTX 760 is not going to be able to handle this game on max.  Unfortunately, as messing around with these settings requires several restarts, this quickly becomes tedious as the game sticks diligently to its setting of launching succesfully 50% of the time.

Additionally, Geforce Experience seems to be on the fritz, so I decide to reboot the PC.  Nope, Geforce hates me too, so it's to time to uninstall him.  While waiting the mandated 20 minutes for that to happen, I go hunting for a fresh copy online, and with so much time on my hands, hit the forums for some light reading, upon which I learn that Geforce seems to not be doing so well in the customer satisfaction index side of things.  Thinking quickly, I decide to forego a software install and opt for just the drivers.  Whew, that was close!

Google Chrome tells me that should be done in 2 hours (thanks to the ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥mongering ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ dickless wondercunts at the DSL company).  I tried launching the game anyway, but the failure rate has rocketed up the charts, like a boy band single, to 100% currently.  I'm going to validate the files then see how many times I can launch the game while the driver downloads

HOUR 2

Well, the validation seems to have helped, but even with all the graphic settings turned down low, the game is still stuttering a lot, particularly with the driving, and the low-res textures are quite nasty, especially the outdoor thugs who are supposed to be wet from the rain and instead look like they're covered in tha goop from the pods in the Matrix.  Having said the Batmobile is hella cool and I can see how gorgeous this game would be if I wasn't trying to run it on a potato. Last but certainly not least, playing as batman himself feels like slipping on your favourite jacket.

One thing that surprised me is that with the bigger map and bigger streets, this is the first game in the series where I'm happy to just sometimes wander the streets on foot instead of zipping about with the batclaw or just sticking to the Batmobile.  The city feels a lot more real than the compact Arkham City and the semi-fake one from Arkham Origins.  I can't wait to explore.  time for some dinner, then a driver install, and we'll see what's what.

More to come...

reviewText:
An Open Letter To WB Interactive Entertainment:

You sons of ♥♥♥♥♥s,

The community waited three years for this, some even spending money for the phoned-in, hollow, shitmuck cash-grab of Arkham Origins to prove to you that this third game was something fans wanted. Something we would wait for. Something we trusted Rocksteady to deliver on. How did you choose to reward this show of faith? By carving Rocksteady's final love letter to a beloved character and franchise into bite-size DLC and mandating the Playstation 4 be the lead platform for development.

You gibbering, mouth-breathing, ♥♥♥♥-filled ♥♥♥♥♥. Your inept meddling in the creation of what could have been one of the most well-recieved, well-reviewed, and fondly remembered gaming series of the last decade has caused it to be little more than a raspy death rattle in lamentation of what could have been. ♥♥♥♥.

Some would call it irony that all of your ill-advised decisions to maximize product ROI" has led to such a costly and
recommended: embarrassing public relations nightmare; rushing a product so obviously far from completion onto market and emphasizing day-one purchases by surgically excising all the notes and chords of the experience and offering them as pre-purchase incentives has earned you nothing but scorn and derision from anyone with a voice.\n\nYour corporate ineptitude
voteText: and complete failure to understand the very market you seek to monetize has done you no favors and
helpfulPercent: most reprehensibly of all
votesHelpful: has damaged Rocksteady's reputation
votesTotal: leaving the young company with a black mark that will not fade for years. They are the Arkham studio
votesFunny: and where once that association brought acclaim and praise
commentsCount: it is now met with muted applause
column16: the low of this final act still burning raw in public memory.\n\nWB Interactive
column17: you have failed. You'll point to console units shipped and worldwide sales totals as a counterpoint
column18: but you know full well the truth. You won't be shocked as you hear your name spoken with barely-concealed scorn at trade shows. You'll be hurt

reviewText: I was so psyched and hyped and ready for this game for so long, and now it's finally here. And this is the most disgustingly bad PC port I've ever played. Origins has a game-breaking glitch that doesn't allow me to get past the VERY FIRST BOSS BATTLE, and it STILL runs better than this. Rocksteady, you've got a lot more to do right now than just telling us to download AMD software updates that I ALREADY HAVE. FIX IT, YOU F*CKERS. I can't play it, and I can't get my money back! This rests with YOU.\n\nUpdate: I set my MaxFPS cap to 60 and tried again. Got into the VERY FIRST FIGHT and the game froze five different times. It's easy to get a Flawless Freeflow bonus when you get a solid minute to predict your enemies' next moves. I can run TF2 at 100+ FPS IN THE MIDDLE OF HEAVY COMBAT. I run Sniper Elite 3 and Max Payne 3 at 60+ FPS at all times. GTA V was PC optimized 100x better than this, despite it taking over a year to get it out there. At least Rockstar took the time to develop a product they knew we would love (graphics-wise, anyway). But one of the greatest video game series to ever be created gives us this f*cking sh*t port? I don't care if you're done with Batman after this, Rocksteady. This. Is. Bull. Sh*t.

reviewText:
I tried to like this game, I really did. I loved the first two games (Origins was meh), and this one was certainly fun with the BatTank.

But damn it Iron Galaxy, this is one of the worst PC Ports in ages, and yes it is a port. In addition to the HORRID graphical glitches, framerate drops and others that have been mentioned by over 4000 reviewers, there's other glaring issues that show that whoever ported this doesn't know what they're doing.

You know the control scheme used in the first three games? Yeah that's completely gone now. Instead, takedowns have been relocated to alt+1" from the usual places on the keyboard
date: so when you press e to try to take down badguys
recommended: you'll go "huh" as the auto-takedown move is now moved to a two step combo that forces you to think about it in the middle of combat.\n\nWant to drop down quickly? NOPE. Rocksteady decided to make use of that middle mouse button

voteText: trying to execute a drop attack from a ledge makes Batman just jump to the left on his perch if you're on a ledge for some reason.\n\nThe absolute worst part *SPOILER ALERT* is when you're in the Ace Chemical Plant trying to minimize the bomb's explosion radius. For some stupid reason

reviewText:
Second release: So nothing has changed. The games is still unoptimized mess (well, compared to what we had for the first 3 months it is amazing). The only good thing they did is actually promising every single Arkham Game and TF2 items for those who kept this abomination, except that a ton of people already had other Arkham games, since there is no point of buying this one, if you haven't played previous installments.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME UNLESS IT IS 90% OFF!

NEW: Well, the fixed a lot of problems so now I can play at 60 fps (still not stable), with low textures and shadows (otherwise fps is around 30 fps). Do I recommend this game? No, and I never will. There is a thing called YouTube, go there if you want to see how the story ends. Don't EVER buy it, just to show developers that people are smarter than they think, so they won't be able to release a broken product just to fix it later. Go buy The Phantom Pain that is perfect in every way, or go buy Mad Max, that works perfectly at stable 60 fps on max settings and is fun to play. Stay away from this game even though they fixed it. It is the worst Batman game out of Arkham series (including Origins), and not because, but thanks to one of the worst launch ever. Because it wasn't working players where looking critically at the entire game, not just optimization, and oh boy it is bad. While the main story is a lot of fun (except for Arkham Knight, because this character was awful), but every other aspect is far from good. Every single side-quest is boring and univentive, the Batmobile is pushed down your throat until you scream STOP!"

DON'T buy this game.

reviewText:
Rockstead screwed Pc fans.  They tool the money and RAN.  I missed out of the refund because I figured they would patch it soon and then the DLC would be hitting.  Needless to say, It's a few months later and I still can't even SEE the dlc, let alone download or play what I paid for.


In all fairness, the game play can be great, and there is a lot of great stuff, but over all?  I wouldn't recommend it.  They really lost track of who Batman is, some of the VO is subpar, the story is kind of weak in terms of the Arhkam Knight, WAY too much time was spent on the Batmobile and not things to do with it making missions tedious after the first two or three times, there are numerous times they take the Batman Mythos and just wipe their asses with it... much like they did with the PC players...

Even If you're a die hard Batman fan, or even just a fan of this series, this game can easily wait until it's $7 on a steamsale.  Don't pay full price for this, and certainly don't waste money on DLC that you'll never see either.  Wait until it's all out AND on sale.

reviewText:
AVOID.
I will update this should the game ever be truly fixed, but it's looking less and less likely.

Arkham Knight is a great game, ruined on PC by a terrible port, made almost bearable over the course of several months. However, this is *not* why I'm telling you not to buy this game.

I imagined writing this review closer to Christmas, praising the game and giving Rocksteady/WB a verbose metaphorical pat on the back for taking the time to fix it fully. Unfortunately, the developers (or more likely, the publishers) have recently decided to forgo bringing the port up to par.

Temperamental shader and texture glitches have been present and untouched since June. We will never have multiGPU support, and, more importantly, the game's horrible memory allocation - a side effect of heavy optimization compromises made for consoles - is never going to be improved.

Arkham Asylum, City and Origins are all great PC games which will be enjoyed for years to come. They're classics.

As it stands, Arkham Knight is still a mess. I'm not sure how anyone passionate about making games could submit a port of a game of this calibre to Steam, and then come out with this half-hearted well
date: we tried" attitude to fixing it."
helpfulPercent: 10 of 10 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It has its moments.

We all know it's a horrendous port, that means don't buy it unless you have a beefy computer. Do not buy it either if you feel publishers and developpers alike should put more care into their console ports. You'll not miss much anyway. It's an okay game, but certainly not a must-buy; pick it when it's on sale if you have 20/30 hours, money to sink, and nothing else to do. It's more of the same Arkham gameplay with even less detective or infiltration phases; that is to say it does not require any kind of effort. Having the Batmobile is nice, but it was a little overused for my taste, as what you do with it during the main campaign is always the same. If you want to fully complete the game, you will have to do all of Riddler's challenges, which is a chore.

I haven't played the DLCs, and I certainly won't, so I cannot say anything about their quality.

(Disclaimer: I got it for free as part of my new Nvidia GPU purchase, which means I was not angry like the people who legitimately were, as they paid full price for a game that was - and some would argue, still is - an unpolished turd.)

reviewText:
This game in its current state is more than playable. I run an Intel i7 with 8 gigs of ram and a 4 gig GTX 960 and average around 55 FPS in 1080p on Win 7. There are some frame drops at certain times where a lot is going on but really not that big of a deal. The graphics are done with extreme detail even down to the assets. I understand the complaint from those who pre-ordered as I would not be happy either. Now I am not saying it is okay but we all make mistakes. Now to rate the game as a whole for what it is worth without a childish hop on the bandwagon review. I will talk about this game going forward for anyone who would like to purchase it.

The open world design grant a great backbone to this games development which also subsequently allows for DLC to be added into the game seamlessly. The vanilla story" if you will is great with a twisted plot that any comic/batman fan should enjoy. You can attack many different scenarios in a way that suits your playing style. If your bored you can wander the streets like in a GTA game and cause havoc or in this case beat up some bad guys.

Now how does the game run. My GPU is NOT overclocked and I get 55+ FPS 90% of the time. I can only imagine a 970/980/TITAN to be way better. This is with all my settings maxed out on high with the exception of the nvidia interactive smoke
hoursPlayed: etc which is disabled. Now if you don't have a 900 series GPU or 4+ gigs VRAM this is where it might get tricky. I does use most of my VRAM. I don't have a 750 ti so I can't compare. As I don't know how it will run on 2 gigs VRAM or the older GPUs. It may be a struggle. I can say that anything above a 960 4GB shouldn't get a complaint.\n\nI suggest every future reviewer leave your system specifications in the review so it can be judged for accuracy."

reviewText:
Guys, you don't have to get mad! I know what happened here. Clearly, Rocksteady created a REAL fear toxin that was released upon us all when we bought the game! It's temporary, I'm sure. It'll wear off eventually. It's why we think this game's a complete piece of ♥♥♥!

But, on to the serious part.




I was really hyped for this game. Truly, I was. The issues people have been facing in this game are unbelievable, and it makes me very aggitated. I expected better from a Batman: Arkham game. This pc port is one of, if not THE, worst I've seen. Now, my computer can't run this game well. (Not in the way most are experiencing. I have yet to upgrade my PC to actually TEST the gameplay myself, but I had to write this as a warning.) Yes, this is a WARNING. WB, Rocksteady, WHOEVER ported this over and WHOEVER did not fix these issues: I will not pre-order or buy a AAA title again unless this issue gets QUICKLY fixed. When I get my new computer in a couple of weeks, I will come back and give this game a proper review. Still, be warned. If you do not swiftly act and make this port top-notch soon, I will have to warn others (Although, who DOESN'T know how horrid this port is?), which can hurt your sales, and hurt other AAA sales. I'm sure others are already doing this.

YOU CAN FIX THIS. You can make this right. Fix this port. Make us, your customers, happy. Make us not regret buying this for full price and getting a practically broken game. I can understand this mix-up if you act fast. Many games had horrible launches. Battlefield 4, Watchdogs, Mortal Kombat X, and, oh, ARKHAM ORIGINS AND ARKHAM CITY are some good examples. Don't let this become a trend. Fix this issue.

I know you can. JUST DO IT. YES, YOU CAN. You said you'd do it tomorrow yesterday. Just.. DO IT. Don't let OUR dreams stay dreams! DO IT.

You broke my heart. Mend it.

Thank you and good luck (For now),
Leelah

[EDIT] - I forgot to mention that this game is automatically locked at 30 FPS. Beware. This is for ALL computers.

reviewText:
Update on the re-release patch (28/10/2015). Still as broken as it ever was, windows 7 + 8gb ram = memory leak after less than 5 minutes in the batmobile, a bit longer on foot/gliding. Game can easily be completely unplayable on your system due to a memory leak and there is not a thing you can do about it, even the dev team gave up on fixing this issue. Just for reference, my PC runs AC Unity at a constant 30 fps with all settings set to high, so it's definitely strong enough to run this game, hell, it runs fine for 1 minute, it's just that this game's memory management doesn't function properly. I reinstalled it 5 times on my PC with various gpu drivers, and all kinds of pagefile scenarios I could think of, it just doesn't work properly on my machine (I guess after having great luck with running AC Unity and Watch_Dogs - this one runs at above 50fps most of the time on high settings, my luck with bad PC ports had run out) - to save yourself a headache, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME ON PC!!! Don't reward sloppy PC devs with your hard earned money, please.
The rest of my review was written on release date (the actual release date) and editing it even slightly would probably just p!ss me the eff off, so I'll leave it like this, unless the game actually becomes playable at some point.
If you're one of those people who thought Origins was a bad Arkham game, has Rocksteady got a surprise for you.

So yeah, let's make an UE3 game look like it's using Cryengine 3, but let's definitely not buy a Cryengine license, cause money yo!

If you have a card with 2gb of vram (if you have less, look the other way, the game will not run at all), be prepared to lower the settings to the bare minimum (that's right! all 3 settings, all of the 3 settings that are 3... THREE... 3... 3... 3, not 2, definitely not 4, but 3), lower the resolution below 1080p and expect huge fps dips and chugging and even complete pauses in gameplay (0 fps). This is always present in the driving sections, and often while gliding across the map or diving to take out an enemy.

Can't turn off blur, depth of field, dynamic lights or shadows, film grain, chromatic aberration, you can just make your game look super blurry by lowering the textures, and have all these wonderful frame dropping filters on, to make your eyes bleed a bit more.

Let's say a thing or two about the gameplay (after all I suffered through this game for 20+ hours so far) - It's a mix between the good old Arkham Asylum/City laser precise and very responsive combat, and some of the worst predator encounters I have experienced in an Arkham game, the enemy placement is a mess, there are too many enemies in every predator encounter I came across, and they decreased the number of ceiling grappling points drastically, so often you're in underground shafts or making those 2 ceiling grappling points work somehow.

The story SO FAR" is not great

reviewText:
Edit: November 4th 2015 - still runs like trash!

Playing at 1080P on Low settings will cause you to run out of VRAM on a 2GB card so you have to run at 900P! (Can't get a decent stable framerate with a GTX 950 at all)

The Batmobile driving sections for me are where the most issues are. (I was following Gordon who was driving a police car and the game dropped to around 15 FPS)

The frame rate goes up and down and up and down and will probably make you motion sick.

The rain is still borked and AA settings is very poorly implemented and not up to the task.

I had to install the game on a SSD to get it to boot properly as it was taking several mins to start from my 1TB HDD (Common issue since last patch) I've got 16GB Ram and it makes no difference to performance despite developer claims that 12GB or more helps on Windows 10. (I also have a swap file as well)

If you have a GTX 970 or 980t Ti you can probably play this as you have the GPU power and VRAM to throw at it. (Don't expect amazing framerates however)

If you have a 2GB card I would say forget it and save your money or buy it on a Console instead. (There is a good game here, although the Batmobile is over used to the point of tedium, the combat and story are good and have evolved from the original games) I can't recommend the PC version to anybody with all the unresolved performance issues.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

My original launch review below.

Currently runs like hot garbage on a GTX 750 Ti, Nvidia's humble mainstream 1080P card is crippled by this game, barely utilises all 4 cores of my overclocked 860k and floods the VRAM of my 750 Ti. Framerate falls off of a cliff when you get in the Batmobile.  Needs a patch or two before it functions properly. Graphics Options are limited, 30 FPS frame cap cripples performance.

Edit 1: I got a playable framerate other than a tiny drop once at 1366 x 768, however the batmobile sections still make my eyes bleed from framerate tanking.

The fighting in this game is much better than the previous games as Batman has a greater moveset from the off. I will be more positive once there is performace issues patch.

reviewText:
You deserve better!

Do not buy this game for fulll price it is NOT WORTH IT.  The reviews are only *mixed* because of trolls just making joke positive reviews.

Cons:
Game does not get steady 60fps with gtx 980 even on lowest settings(frequent drops to under 30 regardless).  Game still hogs memory for no reason, and apparently the windows 7 memory leak was never fixed(i can't confirm this as i updated to 10) but it's something to be wary of.

Too many batmobile boss fights

Pros:
It's a pretty good arkham game, open world to explore with intersting things to do.  Story is pretty telegraphed but as a batman fan it was still engaging enough for to keep my interest the whole time, and the voice acting and delivery for the most part was terrific.  I felt the batmobile stuff was fine for the most part but the real fun in the game is flying around gotham city defying the laws of physics.

If you want arkham knight, get it at a discount or get a console and have the experience the game was designed for.  4 months off shelves and it's only moderately playable, you deserve better.

5/10

reviewText:
Re-release Review:
With the game's re-release, I went and tested it again for half hour to see any changes. There's still frame drops when summoning the Batmobile and drifting with it. This is with 1080 and all maxed with the following specs: i7, GTX970, 16GB RAM, SSD (OS, Steam, and AK in SSD), with all drivers updated. In short, it didn't feel like there were any changes at all - way below 60fps and occassional dips to single digits when summoning the/drifting with the Batmobile. For me, this means the Excavator encounter, chasing something/someone, and fighting myriad drones are still going to be sh*t. There are still texture streaming changes that if there are a lot of things going on or you quickly look at an area with lots of textures and details, the texture streaming is not always fluid and seamless - you still notice some textures load slowly.

There are reports that gliding slows it downs too (aka framedrops), although I didn't experience it. There are still the gliding bug/glitch where you will do a nosedive, even if you didn't initiate it - I still experience that from time to time.

Some people couldn't start the game, which could be something about users changing game files, according to WB official statements. The solution is to delete the changed files and then verify cache, so the files that were deleted are regenerated, using the latest version of said files.

Some reports the game takes a while to start, which could be affecting mostly those running the game in mechanical drives (non-SSD), which is still bad - the game shouldn't be too taxing that mechanical drives become a problem. If I'm already experiencing slowdowns and (sometimes) texture streaming issues with the game in my SSD, I'm certain it's going to be worse if I put it in one of my mechanical drives with 7.2k RPM.

The re-release/patch notes did not identify any gamebreaking bugs that were fixed, such as the locked door trap bug, or the drone bug. Also, it seems that to run the game without paging, you need 12GB.

Verdict: still Not Recommended. 6/10

As stated, they barely fix anything, as far as optimizing it further and fixing known bugs and glitches. It seems that they prioritized getting the DLCs and the re-release ready.

However, they intend to make amends for those who waited for a game that's still far from optimal". They intend to give those affected with the entire Arkham library
date: along with a community challenge map pack exclusive to the PC version for a while (supposedly about a week) before it becomes multiplat
recommended:
and some Arkham games-themed TF2 junk.

Here's the problem with that:
- What if you already own all Arkham games? Are you just f*cked? Will they even let you choose another WB game?
- What if you don't like any other Arkham game? Can't you choose some other WB game? Can't you get a Season Pass of any WB game instead?
- Another challenge map pack? A story pack would've been better than another challenge map pack

reviewText:
Well, what to say about this game...
The game itself is great, feels and plays much better than previous installments, I had a lot of fun in these 5 hours that I (tryed to) play, even though I didn't like the previous games very much. The story is also very interesting for me, and the mission design is awesome. I gladly recommend the game, even if you're not a fan on the series (like me), but FOR THE LOVE OF GOD, DON'T BUY IT FOR PC. If you have a console, be my guest and have fun. If you don't, then you should probably pass on this game. The port is TERRIBLE. The game barely runs on 30 fps, doesn't matter which graphics options I pick, while for example Witcher 3 runs completely maxed out without issues. The game also has a FPS lock on 30 so unless you edit a game file by hand, you're not going any higher than that. And last but not least, the graphics features are worse than the PS4 version. How the hell is that even possible?

TL;DR:
Buy for console, it's an awesome game.
Don't get it for PC, it's terrible. If you don't have a console, just pass on the game.

reviewText:
When Arkham Knight was announced I knew I needed to play it, so to wait for it, I started to play the 3 previous games.
I migrated to PC gaming recently from consoles, so they were the first games I played on PC, the experience was awesome, graphics were amazing, history was incredible, I simple just love them.

I bought Arkham Knight right after its release, but I was still playing Arkham City at that time and I still needed to play Arkham Origins, also at that time the complains about performance started and the game was temporally removed from Steam. I didn't asked for a refund since I really wanted to play it whenever it would be available again, so I just waited.

When I finished Arkham Origins I was ready to start with Arkham Knight, at that time it came back to Steam and most performance issues were fixed, I'm not going to lie you, I spend some time trying to configure the video settings to get the best performance/quality, and I did it, my PC is an Alienware Alpha which has a GeForce GTX 860M graphics card with 2GB of GDDR5, it is not too big but worked for me. I was able to play and enjoy this game a lot.

So now that I talked about the performance experience, I want to talk about my experience with the story of the game.
For some reason in these games you really feel you are Batman, the missions and information got your attention, there are details everywhere and it doesn't feel repetitive like other open-world games. The introduction of the batmobile feels weird at the beginning, but you get familiar with it quickly, sometimes you really wish to have it right next to you. Personally I prefer the enemies that represent mystic, dark or powerful characters over the enemies that are just mobs or militia, which were the main characters on this game, thinking about this detail, I believe Arkham City was better, but for the rest, I think Arkham Knight is offering a great improvement, it is good to learn about all the Batman family story and work with all of them.

I really recommend it because I loved it. Performance issues are fixed and this game is playable now, don't worry about it.
PD: The batsuit in this game is the best suit I have ever seen in Batman movies or games, I really wanted this suit for Batman v Superman, but anyway...
